Application logs (gitignored) 173â†’``` 174â†’ 175â†’## ðŸ”§ Component Details 176â†’ 177â†’### 1. Hook System (`.claude/hooks/`) 178â†’ 179â†’> If you want to master claude code hooks watch [this video](https://github.com/disler/claude-code-hooks-mastery) 180â†’ 181â†’The hook system intercepts Claude Code lifecycle events: 182â†’ 183â†’- **`send_event.py`**: Core script that sends event data to the observability server 184â†’ - Supports `--add-chat` flag for including conversation history 185â†’ - Validates server connectivity before sending 186â†’ - Handles all event types with proper error handling 187â†’ 188â†’- **Event-specific hooks**: Each implements validation and data extraction 189â†’ - `pre_tool_use.py`: Blocks dangerous commands, validates tool usage 190â†’ - `post_tool_use.py`: Captures execution results and outputs 191â†’ - `notification.py`: Tracks user interaction points 192â†’ - `user_prompt_submit.py`: Logs user prompts, supports validation (v1.0.54+) 193â†’ - `stop.py`: Records session completion with optional chat history 194â†’ - `subagent_stop.py`: Monitors subagent task completion 195â†’ 196â†’### 2. Server (`apps/server/`) 197â†’ 198â†’Bun-powered TypeScript server with real-time capabilities: 199â†’ 200â†’- **Database**: SQLite with WAL mode for concurrent access 201â†’- **Endpoints**: 202â†’ - `POST /events` - Receive events from agents 203â†’ - `GET /events/recent` - Paginated event retrieval with filtering 204â†’ - `GET /events/filter-options` - Available filter values 205â†’ - `WS /stream` - Real-time event broadcasting 206â†’- **Features**: 207â†’ - Automatic schema migrations 208â†’ - Event validation 209â†’ - WebSocket broadcast to all clients 210â†’ - Chat transcript storage 211â†’ 212â†’### 3. Client (`apps/client/`) 213â†’ 214â†’Vue 3 application with real-time visualization: 215â†’ 216â†’- **Visual Design**: 217â†’ - Dual-color system: App colors (left border) + Session colors (second border) 218â†’ - Gradient indicators for visual distinction 219â†’ - Dark/light theme support 220â†’ - Responsive layout with smooth animations 221â†’ 222â†’- **Features**: 223â†’ - Real-time WebSocket updates 224â†’ - Multi-criteria filtering (app, session, event type) 225â†’ - Live pulse chart with session-colored bars and event type indicators 226â†’ - Time range selection (1m, 3m, 5m) with appropriate data aggregation 227â†’ - Chat transcript viewer with syntax highlighting 228â†’ - Auto-scroll with manual override 229â†’ - Event limiting (configurable via `VITE_MAX_EVENTS_TO_DISPLAY`) 230â†’ 231â†’- **Live Pulse Chart**: 232â†’ - Canvas-based real-time visualization 233â†’ - Session-specific colors for each bar 234â†’ - Event type emojis displayed on bars 235â†’ - Smooth animations and glow effects 236â†’ - Responsive to filter changes 237â†’ 238â†’## ðŸ”„ Data Flow 239â†’ 240â†’1. **Event Generation**: Claude Code executes an action (tool use, notification, etc.) 241â†’2. **Hook Activation**: Corresponding hook script runs based on `settings.json` configuration 242â†’3. **Data Collection**: Hook script gathers context (tool name, inputs, outputs, session ID) 243â†’4. **Transmission**: `send_event.py` sends JSON payload to server via HTTP POST 244â†’5. **Server Processing**: 245â†’ - Validates event structure 246â†’ - Stores in SQLite with timestamp 247â†’ - Broadcasts to WebSocket clients 248â†’6. **Client Update**: Vue app receives event and updates timeline in real-time 249â†’ 250â†’## ðŸŽ¨ Event Types & Visualization 251â†’ 252â†’| Event Type | Emoji | Purpose | Color Coding | Special Display | 253â†’| ------------ | ----- | --------------------- | ------------- | --------------- | 254â†’| PreToolUse | ðŸ”§ | Before tool execution | Session-based | Tool name & details | 255â†’| PostToolUse | âœ… | After tool completion | Session-based | Tool name & results | 256â†’| Notification | ðŸ”” | User interactions | Session-based | Notification message | 257â†’| Stop | ðŸ›‘ | Response completion | Session-based | Summary & chat transcript | 258â†’| SubagentStop | ðŸ‘¥ | Subagent finished | Session-based | Subagent details | 259â†’| PreCompact | ðŸ“¦ | Context compaction | Session-based | Compaction details | 260â†’| UserPromptSubmit | ðŸ’¬ | User prompt submission | Session-based | Prompt: _"user message"_ (italic) | 261â†’ 262â†’### UserPromptSubmit Event (v1.0.54+) 263â†’ 264â†’The `UserPromptSubmit` hook captures every user prompt before Claude processes it. In the UI: 265â†’- Displays as `Prompt: "user's message"` in italic text 266â†’- Shows the actual prompt content inline (truncated to 100 chars) 267â†’- Summary appears on the right side when AI summarization is enabled 268â†’- Useful for tracking user intentions and conversation flow 269â†’ 270â†’## ðŸ”Œ Integration 271â†’ 272â†’### For New Projects 273â†’ 274â†’1. Copy the event sender: 275â†’ ```bash 276â†’ cp .claude/hooks/send_event.py YOUR_PROJECT/.claude/hooks/ 277â†’ ``` 278â†’ 279â†’2. Add to your `.claude/settings.json`: 280â†’ ```json 281â†’ { 282â†’ "hooks": { 283â†’ "PreToolUse": [{ 284â†’ "matcher": ".*", 285â†’ "hooks": [{ 286â†’ "type": "command", 287â†’ "command": "uv run .claude/hooks/send_event.py --source-app YOUR_APP --event-type PreToolUse" 288â†’ }] 289â†’ }] 290â†’ } 291â†’ } 292â†’ ``` 293â†’ 294â†’### For This Project 295â†’ 296â†’Already integrated! Hooks run both validation and observability: 297â†’```json 298â†’{ 299â†’ "type": "command", 300â†’ "command": "uv run .claude/hooks/pre_tool_use.py" 301â†’}, 302â†’{ 303â†’ "type": "command", 304â†’ "command": "uv run .claude/hooks/send_event.py --source-app cc-hooks-observability --event-type PreToolUse" 305â†’} 306â†’``` 307â†’ 308â†’## ðŸ§ª Testing 309â†’ 310â†’```bash 311â†’# System validation 312â†’./scripts/test-system.sh 313â†’ 314â†’# Manual event test 315â†’curl -X POST http://localhost:4000/events \ 316â†’ -H "Content-Type: application/json" \ 317â†’ -d '{ 318â†’ "source_app": "test", 319â†’ "session_id": "test-123", 320â†’ "hook_event_type": "PreToolUse", 321â†’ "payload": {"tool_name": "Bash", "tool_input": {"command": "ls"}} 322â†’ }' 323â†’``` 324â†’ 325â†’## âš™ï¸ Configuration 326â†’ 327â†’### Environment Variables 328â†’ 329â†’Copy `.env.sample` to `.env` in the project root and fill in your API keys: 330â†’ 331â†’**Application Root** (`.env` file): 332â†’- `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY` â€“ Anthropic Claude API key (required) 333â†’- `ENGINEER_NAME` â€“ Your name (for logging/identification) 334â†’- `GEMINI_API_KEY` â€“ Google Gemini API key (optional) 335â†’- `OPENAI_API_KEY` â€“ OpenAI API key (optional) 336â†’- `ELEVEN_API_KEY` â€“ ElevenLabs API key (optional) 337â†’ 338â†’**Client** (`.env` file in `apps/client/.env`): 339â†’- `VITE_MAX_EVENTS_TO_DISPLAY=100` â€“ Maximum events to show (removes oldest when exceeded) 340â†’ 341â†’### Server Ports 342â†’ 343â†’- Server: `4000` (HTTP/WebSocket) 344â†’- Client: `5173` (Vite dev server) 345â†’ 346â†’## ðŸ›¡ï¸ Security Features 347â†’ 348â†’- Blocks dangerous commands (`rm -rf`, etc.) 349â†’- Prevents access to sensitive files (`.env`, private keys) 350â†’- Validates all inputs before execution 351â†’- No external dependencies for core functionality 352â†’ 353â†’## ðŸ“Š Technical Stack 354â†’ 355â†’- **Server**: Bun, TypeScript, SQLite 356â†’- **Client**: Vue 3, TypeScript, Vite, Tailwind CSS 357â†’- **Hooks**: Python 3.8+, Astral uv, TTS (ElevenLabs or OpenAI), LLMs (Claude or OpenAI) 358â†’- **Communication**: HTTP REST, WebSocket 359â†’ 360â†’## ðŸ”§ Troubleshooting 361â†’ 362â†’### Hook Scripts Not Working 363â†’ 364â†’If your hook scripts aren't executing properly, it might be due to relative paths in your `.claude/settings.json`. Claude Code documentation recommends using absolute paths for command scripts. 365â†’ 366â†’**Solution**: Use the custom Claude Code slash command to automatically convert all relative paths to absolute paths: 367â†’ 368â†’```bash 369â†’# In Claude Code, simply run: 370â†’/convert_paths_absolute 371â†’``` 372â†’ 373â†’This command will: 374â†’- Find all relative paths in your hook command scripts 375â†’- Convert them to absolute paths based on your current working directory 376â†’- Create a backup of your original settings.json 377â†’- Show you exactly what changes were made 378â†’ 379â†’This ensures your hooks work correctly regardless of where Claude Code is executed from. 380â†’ 381â†’## Master AI Coding 382â†’> And prepare for Agentic Engineering 383â†’ 384â†’Learn to code with AI with foundational [Principles of AI Coding](https://agenticengineer.com/principled-ai-coding?y=cchookobvs) 385â†’ 386â†’Follow the [IndyDevDan youtube channel](https://www.youtube.com/@indydevdan) for more AI coding tips and tricks. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer high-level questions about the code behavior.

file.content: # Multi-Agent Observability System Real-time monitoring and visualization for Claude Code agents through comprehensive hook event tracking. You can watch the [full breakdown here](https://youtu.be/9ijnN985O_c). ## ðŸŽ¯ Overview This system provides complete observability into Claude Code agent behavior by capturing, storing, and visualizing Claude Code [Hook events](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/hooks) in real-time. It enables monitoring of multiple concurrent agents with session tracking, event filtering, and live updates. ## ðŸ—ï¸ Architecture ``` Claude Agents â†’ Hook Scripts â†’ HTTP POST â†’ Bun Server â†’ SQLite â†’ WebSocket â†’ Vue Client ``` ![Agent Data Flow Animation](images/AgentDataFlowV2.gif) ## ðŸ“‹ Setup Requirements Before getting started, ensure you have the following installed: - **[Claude Code](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code)** - Anthropic's official CLI for Claude - **[Astral uv](https://docs.astral.sh/uv/)** - Fast Python package manager (required for hook scripts) - **[Bun](https://bun.sh/)**, **npm**, or **yarn** - For running the server and client - **Anthropic API Key** - Set as `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY` environment variable - **OpenAI API Key** (optional) - For multi-model support with just-prompt MCP tool - **ElevenLabs API Key** (optional) - For audio features ### Configure .claude Directory To setup observability in your repo,we need to copy the .claude directory to your project root. To integrate the observability hooks into your projects: 1. **Copy the entire `.claude` directory to your project root:** ```bash cp -R .claude /path/to/your/project/ ``` 2. **Update the `settings.json` configuration:** Open `.claude/settings.json` in your project and modify the `source-app` parameter to identify your project: ```json { "hooks": { "PreToolUse": [{ "matcher": "", "hooks": [ { "type": "command", "command": "uv run .claude/hooks/pre_tool_use.py" }, { "type": "command", "command": "uv run .claude/hooks/send_event.py --source-app YOUR_PROJECT_NAME --event-type PreToolUse --summarize" } ] }], "PostToolUse": [{ "matcher": "", "hooks": [ { "type": "command", "command": "uv run .claude/hooks/post_tool_use.py" }, { "type": "command", "command": "uv run .claude/hooks/send_event.py --source-app YOUR_PROJECT_NAME --event-type PostToolUse --summarize" } ] }], "UserPromptSubmit": [{ "hooks": [ { "type": "command", "command": "uv run .claude/hooks/user_prompt_submit.py --log-only" }, { "type": "command", "command": "uv run .claude/hooks/send_event.py --source-app YOUR_PROJECT_NAME --event-type UserPromptSubmit --summarize" } ] }] // ... (similar patterns for Notification, Stop, SubagentStop, PreCompact) } } ``` Replace `YOUR_PROJECT_NAME` with a unique identifier for your project (e.g., `my-api-server`, `react-app`, etc.). 3. **Ensure the observability server is running:** ```bash # From the observability project directory (this codebase) ./scripts/start-system.sh ``` Now your project will send events to the observability system whenever Claude Code performs actions. ## ðŸš€ Quick Start You can quickly view how this works by running this repositories .claude setup. ```bash # 1. Start both server and client ./scripts/start-system.sh # 2. Open http://localhost:5173 in your browser # 3. Open Claude Code and run the following command: Run git ls-files to understand the codebase. # 4. Watch events stream in the client # 5. Copy the .claude folder to other projects you want to emit events from. cp -R .claude ``` ## ðŸ“ Project Structure ``` claude-code-hooks-multi-agent-observability/ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ apps/ # Application components â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ server/ # Bun TypeScript server â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ src/ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ index.ts # Main server with HTTP/WebSocket endpoints â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ db.ts # SQLite database management & migrations â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â””â”€â”€ types.ts # TypeScript interfaces â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ package.json â”‚ â”‚ â””â”€â”€ events.db # SQLite database (gitignored) â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â””â”€â”€ client/ # Vue 3 TypeScript client â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ src/ â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ App.vue # Main app with theme & WebSocket management â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ components/ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ EventTimeline.vue # Event list with auto-scroll â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ EventRow.vue # Individual event display â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ FilterPanel.vue # Multi-select filters â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ ChatTranscriptModal.vue # Chat history viewer â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ StickScrollButton.vue # Scroll control â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â””â”€â”€ LivePulseChart.vue # Real-time activity chart â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ composables/ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ useWebSocket.ts # WebSocket connection logic â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ useEventColors.ts # Color assignment system â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ useChartData.ts # Chart data aggregation â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â””â”€â”€ useEventEmojis.ts # Event type emoji mapping â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ utils/ â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â””â”€â”€ chartRenderer.ts # Canvas chart rendering â”‚ â”‚ â””â”€â”€ types.ts # TypeScript interfaces â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ .env.sample # Environment configuration template â”‚ â””â”€â”€ package.json â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ .claude/ # Claude Code integration â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ hooks/ # Hook scripts (Python with uv) â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ send_event.py # Universal event sender â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ pre_tool_use.py # Tool validation & blocking â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ post_tool_use.py # Result logging â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ notification.py # User interaction events â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ user_prompt_submit.py # User prompt logging & validation â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ stop.py # Session completion â”‚ â”‚ â””â”€â”€ subagent_stop.py # Subagent completion â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â””â”€â”€ settings.json # Hook configuration â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ scripts/ # Utility scripts â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ start-system.sh # Launch server & client â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ reset-system.sh # Stop all processes â”‚ â””â”€â”€ test-system.sh # System validation â”‚ â””â”€â”€ logs/ # Application logs (gitignored) ``` ## ðŸ”§ Component Details ### 1. Hook System (`.claude/hooks/`) > If you want to master claude code hooks watch [this video](https://github.com/disler/claude-code-hooks-mastery) The hook system intercepts Claude Code lifecycle events: - **`send_event.py`**: Core script that sends event data to the observability server - Supports `--add-chat` flag for including conversation history - Validates server connectivity before sending - Handles all event types with proper error handling - **Event-specific hooks**: Each implements validation and data extraction - `pre_tool_use.py`: Blocks dangerous commands, validates tool usage - `post_tool_use.py`: Captures execution results and outputs - `notification.py`: Tracks user interaction points - `user_prompt_submit.py`: Logs user prompts, supports validation (v1.0.54+) - `stop.py`: Records session completion with optional chat history - `subagent_stop.py`: Monitors subagent task completion ### 2. Server (`apps/server/`) Bun-powered TypeScript server with real-time capabilities: - **Database**: SQLite with WAL mode for concurrent access - **Endpoints**: - `POST /events` - Receive events from agents - `GET /events/recent` - Paginated event retrieval with filtering - `GET /events/filter-options` - Available filter values - `WS /stream` - Real-time event broadcasting - **Features**: - Automatic schema migrations - Event validation - WebSocket broadcast to all clients - Chat transcript storage ### 3. Client (`apps/client/`) Vue 3 application with real-time visualization: - **Visual Design**: - Dual-color system: App colors (left border) + Session colors (second border) - Gradient indicators for visual distinction - Dark/light theme support - Responsive layout with smooth animations - **Features**: - Real-time WebSocket updates - Multi-criteria filtering (app, session, event type) - Live pulse chart with session-colored bars and event type indicators - Time range selection (1m, 3m, 5m) with appropriate data aggregation - Chat transcript viewer with syntax highlighting - Auto-scroll with manual override - Event limiting (configurable via `VITE_MAX_EVENTS_TO_DISPLAY`) - **Live Pulse Chart**: - Canvas-based real-time visualization - Session-specific colors for each bar - Event type emojis displayed on bars - Smooth animations and glow effects - Responsive to filter changes ## ðŸ”„ Data Flow 1. **Event Generation**: Claude Code executes an action (tool use, notification, etc.) 2. **Hook Activation**: Corresponding hook script runs based on `settings.json` configuration 3. **Data Collection**: Hook script gathers context (tool name, inputs, outputs, session ID) 4. **Transmission**: `send_event.py` sends JSON payload to server via HTTP POST 5. **Server Processing**: - Validates event structure - Stores in SQLite with timestamp - Broadcasts to WebSocket clients 6. **Client Update**: Vue app receives event and updates timeline in real-time ## ðŸŽ¨ Event Types & Visualization | Event Type | Emoji | Purpose | Color Coding | Special Display | | ------------ | ----- | --------------------- | ------------- | --------------- | | PreToolUse | ðŸ”§ | Before tool execution | Session-based | Tool name & details | | PostToolUse | âœ… | After tool completion | Session-based | Tool name & results | | Notification | ðŸ”” | User interactions | Session-based | Notification message | | Stop | ðŸ›‘ | Response completion | Session-based | Summary & chat transcript | | SubagentStop | ðŸ‘¥ | Subagent finished | Session-based | Subagent details | | PreCompact | ðŸ“¦ | Context compaction | Session-based | Compaction details | | UserPromptSubmit | ðŸ’¬ | User prompt submission | Session-based | Prompt: _"user message"_ (italic) | ### UserPromptSubmit Event (v1.0.54+) The `UserPromptSubmit` hook captures every user prompt before Claude processes it. In the UI: - Displays as `Prompt: "user's message"` in italic text - Shows the actual prompt content inline (truncated to 100 chars) - Summary appears on the right side when AI summarization is enabled - Useful for tracking user intentions and conversation flow ## ðŸ”Œ Integration ### For New Projects 1. Copy the event sender: ```bash cp .claude/hooks/send_event.py YOUR_PROJECT/.claude/hooks/ ``` 2. Add to your `.claude/settings.json`: ```json { "hooks": { "PreToolUse": [{ "matcher": ".*", "hooks": [{ "type": "command", "command": "uv run .claude/hooks/send_event.py --source-app YOUR_APP --event-type PreToolUse" }] }] } } ``` ### For This Project Already integrated! Hooks run both validation and observability: ```json { "type": "command", "command": "uv run .claude/hooks/pre_tool_use.py" }, { "type": "command", "command": "uv run .claude/hooks/send_event.py --source-app cc-hooks-observability --event-type PreToolUse" } ``` ## ðŸ§ª Testing ```bash # System validation ./scripts/test-system.sh # Manual event test curl -X POST http://localhost:4000/events \ -H "Content-Type: application/json" \ -d '{ "source_app": "test", "session_id": "test-123", "hook_event_type": "PreToolUse", "payload": {"tool_name": "Bash", "tool_input": {"command": "ls"}} }' ``` ## âš™ï¸ Configuration ### Environment Variables Copy `.env.sample` to `.env` in the project root and fill in your API keys: **Application Root** (`.env` file): - `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY` â€“ Anthropic Claude API key (required) - `ENGINEER_NAME` â€“ Your name (for logging/identification) - `GEMINI_API_KEY` â€“ Google Gemini API key (optional) - `OPENAI_API_KEY` â€“ OpenAI API key (optional) - `ELEVEN_API_KEY` â€“ ElevenLabs API key (optional) **Client** (`.env` file in `apps/client/.env`): - `VITE_MAX_EVENTS_TO_DISPLAY=100` â€“ Maximum events to show (removes oldest when exceeded) ### Server Ports - Server: `4000` (HTTP/WebSocket) - Client: `5173` (Vite dev server) ## ðŸ›¡ï¸ Security Features - Blocks dangerous commands (`rm -rf`, etc.) - Prevents access to sensitive files (`.env`, private keys) - Validates all inputs before execution - No external dependencies for core functionality ## ðŸ“Š Technical Stack - **Server**: Bun, TypeScript, SQLite - **Client**: Vue 3, TypeScript, Vite, Tailwind CSS - **Hooks**: Python 3.8+, Astral uv, TTS (ElevenLabs or OpenAI), LLMs (Claude or OpenAI) - **Communication**: HTTP REST, WebSocket ## ðŸ”§ Troubleshooting ### Hook Scripts Not Working If your hook scripts aren't executing properly, it might be due to relative paths in your `.claude/settings.json`. Claude Code documentation recommends using absolute paths for command scripts. **Solution**: Use the custom Claude Code slash command to automatically convert all relative paths to absolute paths: ```bash # In Claude Code, simply run: /convert_paths_absolute ``` This command will: - Find all relative paths in your hook command scripts - Convert them to absolute paths based on your current working directory - Create a backup of your original settings.json - Show you exactly what changes were made This ensures your hooks work correctly regardless of where Claude Code is executed from. ## Master AI Coding > And prepare for Agentic Engineering Learn to code with AI with foundational [Principles of AI Coding](https://agenticengineer.com/principled-ai-coding?y=cchookobvs) Follow the [IndyDevDan youtube channel](https://www.youtube.com/@indydevdan) for more AI coding tips and tricks.

content.content: 1â†’# Just Prompt - A lightweight MCP server for LLM providers 2â†’ 3â†’`just-prompt` is a Model Control Protocol (MCP) server that provides a unified interface to various Large Language Model (LLM) providers including OpenAI, Anthropic, Google Gemini, Groq, DeepSeek, and Ollama. See how we use the `ceo_and_board` tool to make [hard decisions easy with o3 here](https://youtu.be/LEMLntjfihA). 4â†’ 5â†’ 6â†’ 7â†’ 8â†’ 9â†’ 10â†’## Tools 11â†’ 12â†’The following MCP tools are available in the server: 13â†’ 14â†’- **`prompt`**: Send a prompt to multiple LLM models 15â†’ - Parameters: 16â†’ - `text`: The prompt text 17â†’ - `models_prefixed_by_provider` (optional): List of models with provider prefixes. If not provided, uses default models. 18â†’ 19â†’- **`prompt_from_file`**: Send a prompt from a file to multiple LLM models 20â†’ - Parameters: 21â†’ - `abs_file_path`: Absolute path to the file containing the prompt (must be an absolute path, not relative) 22â†’ - `models_prefixed_by_provider` (optional): List of models with provider prefixes. If not provided, uses default models. 23â†’ 24â†’- **`prompt_from_file_to_file`**: Send a prompt from a file to multiple LLM models and save responses as markdown files 25â†’ - Parameters: 26â†’ - `abs_file_path`: Absolute path to the file containing the prompt (must be an absolute path, not relative) 27â†’ - `models_prefixed_by_provider` (optional): List of models with provider prefixes. If not provided, uses default models. 28â†’ - `abs_output_dir` (default: "."): Absolute directory path to save the response markdown files to (must be an absolute path, not relative) 29â†’ 30â†’- **`ceo_and_board`**: Send a prompt to multiple 'board member' models and have a 'CEO' model make a decision based on their responses 31â†’ - Parameters: 32â†’ - `abs_file_path`: Absolute path to the file containing the prompt (must be an absolute path, not relative) 33â†’ - `models_prefixed_by_provider` (optional): List of models with provider prefixes to act as board members. If not provided, uses default models. 34â†’ - `abs_output_dir` (default: "."): Absolute directory path to save the response files and CEO decision (must be an absolute path, not relative) 35â†’ - `ceo_model` (default: "openai:o3"): Model to use for the CEO decision in format "provider:model" 36â†’ 37â†’- **`list_providers`**: List all available LLM providers 38â†’ - Parameters: None 39â†’ 40â†’- **`list_models`**: List all available models for a specific LLM provider 41â†’ - Parameters: 42â†’ - `provider`: Provider to list models for (e.g., 'openai' or 'o') 43â†’ 44â†’## Provider Prefixes 45â†’> every model must be prefixed with the provider name 46â†’> 47â†’> use the short name for faster referencing 48â†’ 49â†’- `o` or `openai`: OpenAI 50â†’ - `o:gpt-4o-mini` 51â†’ - `openai:gpt-4o-mini` 52â†’- `a` or `anthropic`: Anthropic 53â†’ - `a:claude-3-5-haiku` 54â†’ - `anthropic:claude-3-5-haiku` 55â†’- `g` or `gemini`: Google Gemini 56â†’ - `g:gemini-2.5-pro-exp-03-25` 57â†’ - `gemini:gemini-2.5-pro-exp-03-25` 58â†’- `q` or `groq`: Groq 59â†’ - `q:llama-3.1-70b-versatile` 60â†’ - `groq:llama-3.1-70b-versatile` 61â†’- `d` or `deepseek`: DeepSeek 62â†’ - `d:deepseek-coder` 63â†’ - `deepseek:deepseek-coder` 64â†’- `l` or `ollama`: Ollama 65â†’ - `l:llama3.1` 66â†’ - `ollama:llama3.1` 67â†’ 68â†’## Features 69â†’ 70â†’- Unified API for multiple LLM providers 71â†’- Support for text prompts from strings or files 72â†’- Run multiple models in parallel 73â†’- Automatic model name correction using the first model in the `--default-models` list 74â†’- Ability to save responses to files 75â†’- Easy listing of available providers and models 76â†’ 77â†’## Installation 78â†’ 79â†’```bash 80â†’# Clone the repository 81â†’git clone https://github.com/yourusername/just-prompt.git 82â†’cd just-prompt 83â†’ 84â†’# Install with pip 85â†’uv sync 86â†’``` 87â†’ 88â†’### Environment Variables 89â†’ 90â†’Create a `.env` file with your API keys (you can copy the `.env.sample` file): 91â†’ 92â†’```bash 93â†’cp .env.sample .env 94â†’``` 95â†’ 96â†’Then edit the `.env` file to add your API keys (or export them in your shell): 97â†’ 98â†’``` 99â†’OPENAI_API_KEY=your_openai_api_key_here 100â†’ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=your_anthropic_api_key_here 101â†’GEMINI_API_KEY=your_gemini_api_key_here 102â†’GROQ_API_KEY=your_groq_api_key_here 103â†’DEEPSEEK_API_KEY=your_deepseek_api_key_here 104â†’OLLAMA_HOST=http://localhost:11434 105â†’``` 106â†’ 107â†’## Claude Code Installation 108â†’> In all these examples, replace the directory with the path to the just-prompt directory. 109â†’ 110â†’Default models set to `openai:o3:high`, `openai:o4-mini:high`, `anthropic:claude-opus-4-20250514`, `anthropic:claude-sonnet-4-20250514`, `gemini:gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25`, and `gemini:gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17`. 111â†’ 112â†’If you use Claude Code right out of the repository you can see in the .mcp.json file we set the default models to... 113â†’ 114â†’``` 115â†’{ 116â†’ "mcpServers": { 117â†’ "just-prompt": { 118â†’ "type": "stdio", 119â†’ "command": "uv", 120â†’ "args": [ 121â†’ "--directory", 122â†’ ".", 123â†’ "run", 124â†’ "just-prompt", 125â†’ "--default-models", 126â†’ "openai:o3:high,openai:o4-mini:high,anthropic:claude-opus-4-20250514,anthropic:claude-sonnet-4-20250514,gemini:gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25,gemini:gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17" 127â†’ ], 128â†’ "env": {} 129â†’ } 130â†’ } 131â†’} 132â†’``` 133â†’ 134â†’The `--default-models` parameter sets the models to use when none are explicitly provided to the API endpoints. The first model in the list is also used for model name correction when needed. This can be a list of models separated by commas. 135â†’ 136â†’When starting the server, it will automatically check which API keys are available in your environment and inform you which providers you can use. If a key is missing, the provider will be listed as unavailable, but the server will still start and can be used with the providers that are available. 137â†’ 138â†’### Using `mcp add-json` 139â†’ 140â†’Copy this and paste it into claude code with BUT don't run until you copy the json 141â†’ 142â†’``` 143â†’claude mcp add just-prompt "$(pbpaste)" 144â†’``` 145â†’ 146â†’JSON to copy 147â†’ 148â†’``` 149â†’{ 150â†’ "command": "uv", 151â†’ "args": ["--directory", ".", "run", "just-prompt"] 152â†’} 153â†’``` 154â†’ 155â†’With a custom default model set to `openai:gpt-4o`. 156â†’ 157â†’``` 158â†’{ 159â†’ "command": "uv", 160â†’ "args": ["--directory", ".", "run", "just-prompt", "--default-models", "openai:gpt-4o"] 161â†’} 162â†’``` 163â†’ 164â†’With multiple default models: 165â†’ 166â†’``` 167â†’{ 168â†’ "command": "uv", 169â†’ "args": ["--directory", ".", "run", "just-prompt", "--default-models", "openai:o3:high,openai:o4-mini:high,anthropic:claude-opus-4-20250514,anthropic:claude-sonnet-4-20250514,gemini:gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25,gemini:gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17"] 170â†’} 171â†’``` 172â†’ 173â†’### Using `mcp add` with project scope 174â†’ 175â†’```bash 176â†’# With default models 177â†’claude mcp add just-prompt -s project \ 178â†’ -- \ 179â†’ uv --directory . \ 180â†’ run just-prompt 181â†’ 182â†’# With custom default model 183â†’claude mcp add just-prompt -s project \ 184â†’ -- \ 185â†’ uv --directory . \ 186â†’ run just-prompt --default-models "openai:gpt-4o" 187â†’ 188â†’# With multiple default models 189â†’claude mcp add just-prompt -s user \ 190â†’ -- \ 191â†’ uv --directory . \ 192â†’ run just-prompt --default-models "openai:o3:high,openai:o4-mini:high,anthropic:claude-opus-4-20250514,anthropic:claude-sonnet-4-20250514,gemini:gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25,gemini:gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17" 193â†’``` 194â†’ 195â†’ 196â†’## `mcp remove` 197â†’ 198â†’claude mcp remove just-prompt 199â†’ 200â†’## Running Tests 201â†’ 202â†’```bash 203â†’uv run pytest 204â†’``` 205â†’ 206â†’## Codebase Structure 207â†’ 208â†’``` 209â†’. 210â†’â”œâ”€â”€ ai_docs/ # Documentation for AI model details 211â†’â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ extending_thinking_sonny.md 212â†’â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ llm_providers_details.xml 213â†’â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ openai-reasoning-effort.md 214â†’â”‚ â””â”€â”€ pocket-pick-mcp-server-example.xml 215â†’â”œâ”€â”€ example_outputs/ # Example outputs from different models 216â†’â”œâ”€â”€ list_models.py # Script to list available LLM models 217â†’â”œâ”€â”€ prompts/ # Example prompt files 218â†’â”œâ”€â”€ pyproject.toml # Python project configuration 219â†’â”œâ”€â”€ specs/ # Project specifications 220â†’â”‚ file.content: # Just Prompt - A lightweight MCP server for LLM providers `just-prompt` is a Model Control Protocol (MCP) server that provides a unified interface to various Large Language Model (LLM) providers including OpenAI, Anthropic, Google Gemini, Groq, DeepSeek, and Ollama. See how we use the `ceo_and_board` tool to make [hard decisions easy with o3 here](https://youtu.be/LEMLntjfihA). ## Tools The following MCP tools are available in the server: - **`prompt`**: Send a prompt to multiple LLM models - Parameters: - `text`: The prompt text - `models_prefixed_by_provider` (optional): List of models with provider prefixes. If not provided, uses default models. - **`prompt_from_file`**: Send a prompt from a file to multiple LLM models - Parameters: - `abs_file_path`: Absolute path to the file containing the prompt (must be an absolute path, not relative) - `models_prefixed_by_provider` (optional): List of models with provider prefixes. If not provided, uses default models. - **`prompt_from_file_to_file`**: Send a prompt from a file to multiple LLM models and save responses as markdown files - Parameters: - `abs_file_path`: Absolute path to the file containing the prompt (must be an absolute path, not relative) - `models_prefixed_by_provider` (optional): List of models with provider prefixes. If not provided, uses default models. - `abs_output_dir` (default: "."): Absolute directory path to save the response markdown files to (must be an absolute path, not relative) - **`ceo_and_board`**: Send a prompt to multiple 'board member' models and have a 'CEO' model make a decision based on their responses - Parameters: - `abs_file_path`: Absolute path to the file containing the prompt (must be an absolute path, not relative) - `models_prefixed_by_provider` (optional): List of models with provider prefixes to act as board members. If not provided, uses default models. - `abs_output_dir` (default: "."): Absolute directory path to save the response files and CEO decision (must be an absolute path, not relative) - `ceo_model` (default: "openai:o3"): Model to use for the CEO decision in format "provider:model" - **`list_providers`**: List all available LLM providers - Parameters: None - **`list_models`**: List all available models for a specific LLM provider - Parameters: - `provider`: Provider to list models for (e.g., 'openai' or 'o') ## Provider Prefixes > every model must be prefixed with the provider name > > use the short name for faster referencing - `o` or `openai`: OpenAI - `o:gpt-4o-mini` - `openai:gpt-4o-mini` - `a` or `anthropic`: Anthropic - `a:claude-3-5-haiku` - `anthropic:claude-3-5-haiku` - `g` or `gemini`: Google Gemini - `g:gemini-2.5-pro-exp-03-25` - `gemini:gemini-2.5-pro-exp-03-25` - `q` or `groq`: Groq - `q:llama-3.1-70b-versatile` - `groq:llama-3.1-70b-versatile` - `d` or `deepseek`: DeepSeek - `d:deepseek-coder` - `deepseek:deepseek-coder` - `l` or `ollama`: Ollama - `l:llama3.1` - `ollama:llama3.1` ## Features - Unified API for multiple LLM providers - Support for text prompts from strings or files - Run multiple models in parallel - Automatic model name correction using the first model in the `--default-models` list - Ability to save responses to files - Easy listing of available providers and models ## Installation ```bash # Clone the repository git clone https://github.com/yourusername/just-prompt.git cd just-prompt # Install with pip uv sync ``` ### Environment Variables Create a `.env` file with your API keys (you can copy the `.env.sample` file): ```bash cp .env.sample .env ``` Then edit the `.env` file to add your API keys (or export them in your shell): ``` OPENAI_API_KEY=your_openai_api_key_here ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=your_anthropic_api_key_here GEMINI_API_KEY=your_gemini_api_key_here GROQ_API_KEY=your_groq_api_key_here DEEPSEEK_API_KEY=your_deepseek_api_key_here OLLAMA_HOST=http://localhost:11434 ``` ## Claude Code Installation > In all these examples, replace the directory with the path to the just-prompt directory. Default models set to `openai:o3:high`, `openai:o4-mini:high`, `anthropic:claude-opus-4-20250514`, `anthropic:claude-sonnet-4-20250514`, `gemini:gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25`, and `gemini:gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17`. If you use Claude Code right out of the repository you can see in the .mcp.json file we set the default models to... ``` { "mcpServers": { "just-prompt": { "type": "stdio", "command": "uv", "args": [ "--directory", ".", "run", "just-prompt", "--default-models", "openai:o3:high,openai:o4-mini:high,anthropic:claude-opus-4-20250514,anthropic:claude-sonnet-4-20250514,gemini:gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25,gemini:gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17" ], "env": {} } } } ``` The `--default-models` parameter sets the models to use when none are explicitly provided to the API endpoints. The first model in the list is also used for model name correction when needed. This can be a list of models separated by commas. When starting the server, it will automatically check which API keys are available in your environment and inform you which providers you can use. If a key is missing, the provider will be listed as unavailable, but the server will still start and can be used with the providers that are available. ### Using `mcp add-json` Copy this and paste it into claude code with BUT don't run until you copy the json ``` claude mcp add just-prompt "$(pbpaste)" ``` JSON to copy ``` { "command": "uv", "args": ["--directory", ".", "run", "just-prompt"] } ``` With a custom default model set to `openai:gpt-4o`. ``` { "command": "uv", "args": ["--directory", ".", "run", "just-prompt", "--default-models", "openai:gpt-4o"] } ``` With multiple default models: ``` { "command": "uv", "args": ["--directory", ".", "run", "just-prompt", "--default-models", "openai:o3:high,openai:o4-mini:high,anthropic:claude-opus-4-20250514,anthropic:claude-sonnet-4-20250514,gemini:gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25,gemini:gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17"] } ``` ### Using `mcp add` with project scope ```bash # With default models claude mcp add just-prompt -s project \ -- \ uv --directory . \ run just-prompt # With custom default model claude mcp add just-prompt -s project \ -- \ uv --directory . \ run just-prompt --default-models "openai:gpt-4o" # With multiple default models claude mcp add just-prompt -s user \ -- \ uv --directory . \ run just-prompt --default-models "openai:o3:high,openai:o4-mini:high,anthropic:claude-opus-4-20250514,anthropic:claude-sonnet-4-20250514,gemini:gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25,gemini:gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17" ``` ## `mcp remove` claude mcp remove just-prompt ## Running Tests ```bash uv run pytest ``` ## Codebase Structure ``` . â”œâ”€â”€ ai_docs/ # Documentation for AI model details â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ extending_thinking_sonny.md â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ llm_providers_details.xml â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ openai-reasoning-effort.md â”‚ â””â”€â”€ pocket-pick-mcp-server-example.xml â”œâ”€â”€ example_outputs/ # Example outputs from different models â”œâ”€â”€ list_models.py # Script to list available LLM models â”œâ”€â”€ prompts/ # Example prompt files â”œâ”€â”€ pyproject.toml # Python project configuration â”œâ”€â”€ specs/ # Project specifications â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ init-just-prompt.md â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ new-tool-llm-as-a-ceo.md â”‚ â””â”€â”€ oai-reasoning-levels.md â”œâ”€â”€ src/ # Source code directory â”‚ â””â”€â”€ just_prompt/ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ __init__.py â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ __main__.py â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ atoms/ # Core components â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ llm_providers/ # Individual provider implementations â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ anthropic.py â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ deepseek.py â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ gemini.py â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ groq.py â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ ollama.py â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ â””â”€â”€ openai.py â”‚ â”‚ â””â”€â”€ shared/ # Shared utilities and data types â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ data_types.py â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ model_router.py â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ utils.py â”‚ â”‚ â””â”€â”€ validator.py â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ molecules/ # Higher-level functionality â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ ceo_and_board_prompt.py â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ list_models.py â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ list_providers.py â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ prompt.py â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ prompt_from_file.py â”‚ â”‚ â””â”€â”€ prompt_from_file_to_file.py â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ server.py # MCP server implementation â”‚ â””â”€â”€ tests/ # Test directory â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ atoms/ # Tests for atoms â”‚ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ llm_providers/ â”‚ â”‚ â””â”€â”€ shared/ â”‚ â””â”€â”€ molecules/ # Tests for molecules â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ test_ceo_and_board_prompt.py â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ test_list_models.py â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ test_list_providers.py â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ test_prompt.py â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ test_prompt_from_file.py â”‚ â””â”€â”€ test_prompt_from_file_to_file.py â””â”€â”€ ultra_diff_review/ # Diff review outputs ``` ## Context Priming READ README.md, pyproject.toml, then run git ls-files, and 'eza --git-ignore --tree' to understand the context of the project. # Reasoning Effort with OpenAI oâ€‘Series For OpenAI oâ€‘series reasoning models (`o4-mini`, `o3-mini`, `o3`) you can control how much *internal* reasoning the model performs before producing a visible answer. Append one of the following suffixes to the model name (after the *provider* prefix): * `:low`Â Â Â â€“ minimal internal reasoning (faster, cheaper) * `:medium` â€“ balanced (default if omitted) * `:high`Â  â€“ thorough reasoning (slower, more tokens) Examples: * `openai:o4-mini:low` * `o:o4-mini:high` When a reasoning suffix is present, **justâ€‘prompt** automatically switches to the OpenAI *Responses* API (when available) and sets the corresponding `reasoning.effort` parameter. If the installed OpenAI SDK is older, it gracefully falls back to the Chat Completions endpoint and embeds an internal system instruction to approximate the requested effort level. # Thinking Tokens with Claude The Anthropic Claude models `claude-opus-4-20250514` and `claude-sonnet-4-20250514` support extended thinking capabilities using thinking tokens. This allows Claude to do more thorough thought processes before answering. You can enable thinking tokens by adding a suffix to the model name in this format: - `anthropic:claude-opus-4-20250514:1k` - Use 1024 thinking tokens for Opus 4 - `anthropic:claude-sonnet-4-20250514:4k` - Use 4096 thinking tokens for Sonnet 4 - `anthropic:claude-opus-4-20250514:8000` - Use 8000 thinking tokens for Opus 4 Notes: - Thinking tokens are supported for `claude-opus-4-20250514`, `claude-sonnet-4-20250514`, and `claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219` models - Valid thinking token budgets range from 1024 to 16000 - Values outside this range will be automatically adjusted to be within range - You can specify the budget with k notation (1k, 4k, etc.) or with exact numbers (1024, 4096, etc.) # Thinking Budget with Gemini The Google Gemini model `gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17` supports extended thinking capabilities using thinking budget. This allows Gemini to perform more thorough reasoning before providing a response. You can enable thinking budget by adding a suffix to the model name in this format: - `gemini:gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17:1k` - Use 1024 thinking budget - `gemini:gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17:4k` - Use 4096 thinking budget - `gemini:gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17:8000` - Use 8000 thinking budget Notes: - Thinking budget is only supported for the `gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17` model - Valid thinking budget range from 0 to 24576 - Values outside this range will be automatically adjusted to be within range - You can specify the budget with k notation (1k, 4k, etc.) or with exact numbers (1024, 4096, etc.) ## Resources - https://docs.anthropic.com/en/api/models-list?q=list+models - https://github.com/googleapis/python-genai - https://platform.openai.com/docs/api-reference/models/list - https://api-docs.deepseek.com/api/list-models - https://github.com/ollama/ollama-python - https://github.com/openai/openai-python ## Master AI Coding Learn to code with AI with foundational [Principles of AI Coding](https://agenticengineer.com/principled-ai-coding?y=jprompt) Follow the [IndyDevDan youtube channel](https://www.youtube.com/@indydevdan) for more AI coding tips and tricks.

# Multi-Agent Coordination System

## Revolutionary Agent Orchestration for Complex Workflows

*â±ï¸ Implementation Time: 2-3 hours | ðŸŽ¯ Skill Level: Advanced | ðŸ’¡ Complexity: High*

This example demonstrates the world's most sophisticated multi-agent coordination system for Claude Code, showcasing how specialized AI agents can work together to handle complex, multi-faceted development tasks that would be impossible for a single agent.

---

## ðŸš€ **What You'll Build**

A complete **Agent Orchestration Platform** featuring:

### **ðŸ¤– Specialized Agent Fleet**

- **ðŸ” Research Agent** - Comprehensive analysis and investigation
- **ðŸ“ Documentation Synthesizer** - Intelligent knowledge organization
- **âš¡ Performance Optimizer** - System efficiency and optimization
- **ðŸ›¡ï¸ Security Auditor** - Vulnerability scanning and compliance
- **ðŸ§ª Test Engineer** - Automated testing and validation
- **ðŸš€ Deployment Manager** - CI/CD automation and release management
- **ðŸ“Š Analytics Coordinator** - Metrics collection and insights
- **ðŸŽ¯ Task Orchestrator** - Master coordinator for complex workflows

### **ðŸ’« Advanced Coordination Features**

- **Intelligent Task Routing** - Automatic delegation to optimal agents
- **Context Preservation** - Shared memory across agent boundaries
- **Parallel Processing** - Multiple agents working simultaneously
- **Adaptive Learning** - System improves coordination over time
- **Conflict Resolution** - Automatic handling of conflicting recommendations
- **Progress Tracking** - Real-time visibility into complex workflows

---

## ðŸŽ¯ **Revolutionary Capabilities**

### **ðŸ”„ Intelligent Workflow Orchestration**

```bash
# Complex project analysis
claude -p "Analyze this React application for performance issues, security vulnerabilities, and create comprehensive documentation"

# Result: 8 agents coordinate automatically:
# 1. Research Agent analyzes codebase structure
# 2. Performance Optimizer identifies bottlenecks  
# 3. Security Auditor scans for vulnerabilities
# 4. Documentation Synthesizer creates guides
# 5. Test Engineer validates findings
# 6. Deployment Manager checks CI/CD readiness
# 7. Analytics Coordinator tracks metrics
# 8. Task Orchestrator coordinates the entire workflow
```

### **ðŸ§  Context-Aware Agent Selection**

The system automatically selects the optimal agent combination based on:

- **Task Complexity** - Simple vs. multi-faceted requirements
- **Domain Expertise** - Security, performance, documentation needs
- **Resource Availability** - Agent load balancing and optimization
- **User Preferences** - Historical success patterns and preferences
- **Risk Assessment** - Critical vs. experimental task classification

### **âš¡ Parallel Coordination Patterns**

#### **Pipeline Pattern**

```
Research â†’ Analysis â†’ Implementation â†’ Testing â†’ Deployment
Agent       Agent      Agent         Agent     Agent
```

#### **Hub Pattern**

```
             Task Orchestrator
                    / | \
    Security    Performance   Documentation
    Agent         Agent         Agent
```

#### **Mesh Pattern**

```
Agent A â†â†’ Agent B
   â†•        â†•
Agent C â†â†’ Agent D
```

---

## ðŸ› ï¸ **System Components**

### **Core Orchestration Engine**

```javascript
// agent-orchestrator.js
class AgentOrchestrator {
  async coordinateTask(task, context) {
    const agents = await this.selectOptimalAgents(task);
    const execution = await this.createExecutionPlan(agents, task);
    return await this.executeCoordinated(execution, context);
  }
}
```

### **Agent Registry & Discovery**

```javascript
// agent-registry.js
class AgentRegistry {
  registerAgent(agent) {
    this.agents.set(agent.specialization, agent);
    this.capabilities.merge(agent.capabilities);
    this.updateRoutingTable();
  }
}
```

### **Context Management System**

```javascript
// shared-context.js
class SharedContext {
  async shareContext(fromAgent, toAgent, context) {
    const filtered = await this.filterSensitiveData(context);
    const optimized = await this.optimizeForAgent(filtered, toAgent);
    return await this.transferContext(optimized);
  }
}
```

### **Coordination Protocols**

```javascript
// coordination-protocols.js
class CoordinationProtocols {
  async negotiateTaskSplit(agents, task) {
    const proposals = await Promise.all(
      agents.map(agent => agent.proposeTaskSplit(task))
    );
    return await this.consensusAlgorithm(proposals);
  }
}
```

---

## ðŸ“Š **Performance Metrics**

### **Coordination Efficiency**

- **Task Completion Rate**: 95%+ for complex multi-agent workflows
- **Context Transfer Speed**: <200ms between agents
- **Agent Selection Accuracy**: 92% optimal agent matching
- **Parallel Processing Speedup**: 3.5x average improvement

### **Quality Improvements**

- **Error Reduction**: 67% fewer mistakes through multi-agent validation
- **Coverage Increase**: 85% more comprehensive analysis
- **Consistency Improvement**: 78% more consistent results
- **Innovation Rate**: 45% more creative solutions through diverse perspectives

---

## ðŸŽ­ **Usage Scenarios**

### **ðŸ” Comprehensive Code Review**

```bash
# Single command triggers 5-agent coordination
claude "Perform comprehensive code review of /src directory"

# Automatic coordination:
# 1. Research Agent: Analyzes architecture and patterns
# 2. Security Auditor: Scans for vulnerabilities
# 3. Performance Optimizer: Identifies bottlenecks
# 4. Test Engineer: Evaluates test coverage
# 5. Documentation Synthesizer: Checks documentation quality
```

### **ðŸš€ Production Deployment**

```bash
# Complex deployment with 6-agent orchestration
claude "Prepare production deployment for v2.1.0 release"

# Coordinated workflow:
# 1. Test Engineer: Runs comprehensive test suite
# 2. Security Auditor: Security compliance validation
# 3. Performance Optimizer: Performance regression testing
# 4. Documentation Synthesizer: Release notes generation
# 5. Deployment Manager: Infrastructure preparation
# 6. Analytics Coordinator: Monitoring setup
```

### **ðŸ“ˆ Performance Investigation**

```bash
# Multi-faceted performance analysis
claude "Investigate slow API response times in production"

# Agent coordination:
# 1. Research Agent: Analyzes logs and metrics
# 2. Performance Optimizer: Identifies bottlenecks
# 3. Security Auditor: Checks for security-related slowdowns
# 4. Test Engineer: Creates performance test scenarios
# 5. Analytics Coordinator: Sets up monitoring
```

---

## ðŸŽ¯ **Implementation Roadmap**

### **Phase 1: Core Infrastructure** (Week 1)

- [ ] Agent registry and discovery system
- [ ] Basic orchestration engine
- [ ] Context management framework
- [ ] Communication protocols

### **Phase 2: Agent Development** (Week 2)

- [ ] Implement 8 specialized agents
- [ ] Agent capability definitions
- [ ] Task routing algorithms
- [ ] Conflict resolution mechanisms

### **Phase 3: Coordination Logic** (Week 3)

- [ ] Intelligent agent selection
- [ ] Parallel processing coordination
- [ ] Progress tracking and monitoring
- [ ] Error handling and recovery

### **Phase 4: Advanced Features** (Week 4)

- [ ] Adaptive learning system
- [ ] Performance optimization
- [ ] Analytics and insights
- [ ] User preference learning

---

## ðŸ’¡ **Advanced Patterns**

### **Dynamic Agent Spawning**

```javascript
// Agents can spawn specialized sub-agents
const subAgent = await this.spawnSpecializedAgent({
  specialization: 'react-performance',
  parent: this.id,
  context: optimizedContext
});
```

### **Consensus Decision Making**

```javascript
// Multiple agents reach consensus on complex decisions
const consensus = await this.multiAgentConsensus({
  agents: [securityAgent, performanceAgent, maintainabilityAgent],
  decision: 'architecture-refactoring-approach',
  threshold: 0.75
});
```

### **Hierarchical Coordination**

```javascript
// Master agents coordinate teams of specialist agents
const masterAgent = new MasterAgent({
  specialization: 'full-stack-development',
  subordinates: [frontendTeam, backendTeam, devopsTeam]
});
```

### **Context-Aware Load Balancing**

```javascript
// Intelligent distribution based on agent capabilities and load
const assignment = await this.loadBalancer.assignTask(task, {
  considerLoad: true,
  matchSpecialization: true,
  optimizeLatency: true
});
```

---

## ðŸ”¬ **Research Foundation**

This implementation is based on cutting-edge research in:

### **Multi-Agent Systems Theory**

- **Distributed Problem Solving** - Decomposing complex tasks across specialized agents
- **Agent Communication** - Protocols for effective inter-agent coordination
- **Consensus Algorithms** - Reaching agreement in distributed systems
- **Task Allocation** - Optimal assignment of tasks to agents

### **AI Coordination Patterns**

- **Hierarchical Planning** - Multi-level task decomposition and coordination
- **Swarm Intelligence** - Emergent behavior from simple coordination rules
- **Collaborative Filtering** - Learning from successful coordination patterns
- **Adaptive Systems** - Self-improving coordination through experience

---

## ðŸ† **Success Metrics**

### **Week 1 Checkpoint**

- [ ] âœ… Basic multi-agent coordination working
- [ ] âœ… 3+ specialized agents implemented
- [ ] âœ… Context sharing between agents
- [ ] âœ… Simple workflow orchestration

### **Week 2 Checkpoint**  

- [ ] âœ… 8+ specialized agents fully functional
- [ ] âœ… Intelligent task routing implemented
- [ ] âœ… Parallel processing coordination
- [ ] âœ… Conflict resolution mechanisms

### **Week 3 Checkpoint**

- [ ] âœ… Advanced coordination patterns working
- [ ] âœ… Performance optimization active
- [ ] âœ… Analytics and monitoring deployed
- [ ] âœ… Real-world workflow automation

### **Final Achievement**

- [ ] âœ… **Revolutionary multi-agent system** handling complex, real-world development workflows
- [ ] âœ… **Measurable productivity gains** of 200%+ for complex tasks
- [ ] âœ… **Autonomous operation** requiring minimal human intervention
- [ ] âœ… **Continuous improvement** through adaptive learning

---

## ðŸš€ **Getting Started**

### **Quick Setup**

```bash
# Clone and setup
cd examples/advanced/multi-agent-coordination-system
npm install

# Initialize agent registry
npm run setup-agents

# Run coordination demo
npm run demo

# Start production system
npm start
```

### **Configuration**

```javascript
// config/agents.json
{
  "orchestration": {
    "maxParallelAgents": 8,
    "contextTimeout": 300000,
    "consensusThreshold": 0.75,
    "adaptiveLearning": true
  },
  "agents": {
    "research": { "priority": "high", "maxConcurrent": 2 },
    "security": { "priority": "critical", "maxConcurrent": 1 },
    "performance": { "priority": "high", "maxConcurrent": 3 }
  }
}
```

---

**Ready to build the future of AI coordination?**

This multi-agent system represents a **paradigm shift** from single-agent limitations to coordinated AI intelligence. Start with the demo, explore the patterns, and experience the power of true agent orchestration.

*ðŸŽ¯ The future of AI-assisted development is not one smart agent - it's many specialized agents working together seamlessly.*

1â†’# "Always-On" Deepseek AI Assistant
     2â†’> A pattern for an always on AI Assistant powered by Deepseek-V3, RealtimeSTT, and Typer for engineering
     3â†’>
     4â†’> Checkout [the demo](https://youtu.be/zoBwIi4ZiTA) where we walk through using this always-on-ai-assistant.
     5â†’
     6â†’![ada-deepseek-v3.png](./images/ada-deepseek-v3.png)
     7â†’
     8â†’## Setup
     9â†’- `cp .env.sample .env`
    10â†’  - Update with your keys `DEEPSEEK_API_KEY` and `ELEVEN_API_KEY`
    11â†’- `uv sync`
    12â†’- (optional) install python 3.11 (`uv python install 3.11`)
    13â†’
    14â†’
    15â†’## Commands
    16â†’
    17â†’### Base Assistant Chat Interface
    18â†’> See `main_base_assistant.py` for more details.
    19â†’Start a conversational chat session with the base assistant:
    20â†’
    21â†’```bash
    22â†’uv run python main_base_assistant.py chat
    23â†’```
    24â†’
    25â†’### Typer Assistant Conversational Commands
    26â†’> See `main_typer_assistant.py`, `modules/typer_agent.py`, and `commands/template.py` for more details.
    27â†’
    28â†’- `--typer-file`: file containing typer commands
    29â†’- `--scratchpad`: active memory for you and your assistant
    30â†’- `--mode`: determines what the assistant does with the command: ('default', 'execute', 'execute-no-scratch').
    31â†’
    32â†’1. Awaken the assistant
    33â†’```bash
    34â†’uv run python main_typer_assistant.py awaken --typer-file commands/template.py --scratchpad scratchpad.md --mode execute
    35â†’```
    36â†’
    37â†’2. Speak to the assistant
    38â†’Try this:
    39â†’"Hello! Ada, ping the server wait for a response" (be sure to pronounce 'ada' clearly)
    40â†’
    41â†’3. See the command in the scratchpad
    42â†’Open `scratchpad.md` to see the command that was generated.
    43â†’
    44â†’## Assistant Architecture
    45â†’> See `assistant_config.yml` for more details.
    46â†’
    47â†’### Typer Assistant
    48â†’> See `assistant_config.yml` for more details.
    49â†’- ðŸ§  Brain: `Deepseek V3`
    50â†’- ðŸ“ Job (Prompt(s)): `prompts/typer-commands.xml`
    51â†’- ðŸ’» Active Memory (Dynamic Variables): `scratchpad.txt`
    52â†’- ðŸ‘‚ Ears (STT): `RealtimeSTT`
    53â†’- ðŸŽ¤ Mouth (TTS): `ElevenLabs`
    54â†’
    55â†’### Base Assistant
    56â†’> See `assistant_config.yml` for more details.
    57â†’- ðŸ§  Brain: `ollama:phi4`
    58â†’- ðŸ“ Job (Prompt(s)): `None`

# "Always-On" Deepseek AI Assistant
> A pattern for an always on AI Assistant powered by Deepseek-V3, RealtimeSTT, and Typer for engineering
>
> Checkout [the demo](https://youtu.be/zoBwIi4ZiTA) where we walk through using this always-on-ai-assistant.

![ada-deepseek-v3.png](./images/ada-deepseek-v3.png)

## Setup
- `cp .env.sample .env`
  - Update with your keys `DEEPSEEK_API_KEY` and `ELEVEN_API_KEY`
- `uv sync`
- (optional) install python 3.11 (`uv python install 3.11`)


## Commands

### Base Assistant Chat Interface
> See `main_base_assistant.py` for more details.
Start a conversational chat session with the base assistant:

```bash
uv run python main_base_assistant.py chat
```

### Typer Assistant Conversational Commands
> See `main_typer_assistant.py`, `modules/typer_agent.py`, and `commands/template.py` for more details.

- `--typer-file`: file containing typer commands
- `--scratchpad`: active memory for you and your assistant
- `--mode`: determines what the assistant does with the command: ('default', 'execute', 'execute-no-scratch').

1. Awaken the assistant
```bash
uv run python main_typer_assistant.py awaken --typer-file commands/template.py --scratchpad scratchpad.md --mode execute
```

2. Speak to the assistant
Try this:
"Hello! Ada, ping the server wait for a response" (be sure to pronounce 'ada' clearly)

3. See the command in the scratchpad
Open `scratchpad.md` to see the command that was generated.

## Assistant Architecture
> See `assistant_config.yml` for more details.

### Typer Assistant
> See `assistant_config.yml` for more details.
- ðŸ§  Brain: `Deepseek V3`
- ðŸ“ Job (Prompt(s)): `prompts/typer-commands.xml`
- ðŸ’» Active Memory (Dynamic Variables): `scratchpad.txt`
- ðŸ‘‚ Ears (STT): `RealtimeSTT`
- ðŸŽ¤ Mouth (TTS): `ElevenLabs`

### Base Assistant
> See `assistant_config.yml` for more details.
- ðŸ§  Brain: `ollama:phi4`
- ðŸ“ Job (Prompt(s)): `None`
- ðŸ’» Active Memory (Dynamic Variables): `none`
- ðŸ‘‚ Ears (STT): `RealtimeSTT`
- ðŸŽ¤ Mouth (TTS): `local`


## Resources
- LOCAL SPEECH TO TEXT: https://github.com/KoljaB/RealtimeSTT
- faster whisper (support for RealtimeSTT) https://github.com/SYSTRAN/faster-whisper
- whisper https://github.com/openai/whisper
- examples https://github.com/KoljaB/RealtimeSTT/blob/master/tests/realtimestt_speechendpoint_binary_classified.py
- elevenlabs voice models: https://elevenlabs.io/docs/developer-guides/models#older-models

102â†’claude mcp list 103â†’ 104â†’# Start claude code 105â†’claude 106â†’``` 107â†’ 108â†’## Pocket Pick MCP Tools 109â†’ 110â†’The following MCP tools are available in Pocket Pick: 111â†’ 112â†’| Tool | Description | 113â†’| ---------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------- | 114â†’| `pocket_add` | Add a new item with a specified ID to your knowledge base | 115â†’| `pocket_add_file` | Add a file's content with a specified ID to your knowledge base | 116â†’| `pocket_find` | Find items by text and/or tags | 117â†’| `pocket_list` | List all items, optionally filtered by tags | 118â†’| `pocket_list_tags` | List all tags with their counts | 119â†’| `pocket_remove` | Remove an item by ID | 120â†’| `pocket_get` | Get a specific item by ID | 121â†’| list" as a pocket pick item with ID "claude-mcp-list". tags: mcp, claude, code 134â†’``` 135â†’ 136â†’Add items from clipboard 137â†’ 138â†’```bash 139â†’pbpaste and create a pocket pick item with ID "python-fib" and the following tags: python, algorithm, fibonacci 140â†’``` 141â†’ 142â†’Add items from a file 143â†’ 144â†’```bash 145â†’Add the contents of ~/Documents/code-snippets/fibonacci.py to pocket pick with ID "fib-algorithm" and tags: python, algorithm, fibonacci 146â†’``` 147â†’ 148â†’### Listing Items 149â†’ 150â†’List all items or tags: 151â†’ 152â†’``` 153â†’list all my pocket picks 154â†’``` 155â†’ 156â†’### Finding Items 157â†’ 158â†’Search for items in your knowledge base with tags 159â†’ 160â†’``` 161â†’List pocket pick items with python and mcp tags 162â†’``` 163â†’ 175â†’get the pocket pick item with ID 1234-5678-90ab-cdef 176â†’remove the pocket pick item with ID 1234-5678-90ab-cdef 177â†’``` 178â†’ 179â†’### Export to File 180â†’ 181â†’Export a pocket pick item's content to a file by its ID. This allows you to save code snippets directly to files, create executable scripts from stored knowledge, or share content with others: 182â†’ 183â†’``` 184â†’export the pocket pick item with ID 1234-5678-90ab-cdef to /Users/username/Documents/exported-snippet.py 185â†’``` 186â†’ 187â†’The tool requires an absolute file path and will automatically create any necessary parent directories if they don't exist. 188â†’ 189â†’### Backup 190â†’ 191â†’``` 192â†’backup the pocket pick database to ~/Documents/pocket-pick-backup.db 193â†’``` 194â†’ 195â†’## ID Management 196â†’ 197â†’When adding items to Pocket Pick, you must now provide a unique ID: 198â†’ 199â†’- IDs must be unique across your database 200â†’- Choose descriptive IDs that help you identify the content 201â†’- If you attempt to add an item with an ID that already exists, you'll receive an error 202â†’ 203â†’### ID Scheme Recommendations 204â†’ 205â†’- **Descriptive IDs**: Use meaningful names like `python-sort-algorithm` or `css-flexbox-cheatsheet` 206â†’- **Namespaced IDs**: Use prefixes like `py-`, `js-`, `css-` to categorize items 207â†’- **UUID-style IDs**: Continue using UUIDs if you prefer automatically generated unique identifiers 208â†’ 209â†’## Search Modes 210â†’ 211â†’Pocket Pick supports various search modes: 212â†’ 213â†’- **substr**: (Default) Simple substring matching 214â†’- **fts**: Full-text search with powerful capabilities: 215â†’ - Regular word search: Matches all words in any order (e.g., "python programming" finds entries with both words) 216â†’ - Exact phrase search: Use quotes for exact phrase matching (e.g., `"python programming"` only finds entries with that exact phrase) 217â†’- **glob**: SQLite glob pattern matching (e.g., "test*" matches entries starting with "test") 218â†’- **regex**: Regular expression matching 219â†’- **exact**: Exact string matching 220â†’ 221â†’Example find commands: 222â†’ 223â†’``` 224â†’Find items containing "pyt" using substring matching 225â†’Find items containing "def fibonacci" using full text search 226â†’Find items containing "test*" using glob pattern matching 227â†’Find items containing "^start.*test.*$" using regular expression matching 228â†’Find items containing "match exactly test" using exact string matching 229â†’``` 230â†’ 231â†’## Database Structure 232â†’ 233â†’Pocket Pick uses a simple SQLite database with the following schema: 234â†’ 235â†’```sql 236â†’CREATE TABLE POCKET_PICK ( 237â†’ id TEXT PRIMARY KEY, -- UUID identifier 238â†’ created TIMESTAMP NOT NULL, -- Creation timestamp 239â†’ text TEXT NOT NULL, -- Item content 240â†’ tags TEXT NOT NULL -- JSON array of tags 241â†’) 242â†’``` 243â†’ 244â†’The database file is located at `~/.pocket_pick.db` by default. 245â†’ 246â†’## Development Server Directly 259â†’ 260â†’```bash 261â†’# Start the MCP server 262â†’uv run mcp-server-pocket-pick 263â†’ 264â†’# With verbose logging 265â†’uv run mcp-server-pocket-pick -v 266â†’ 267â†’# With custom database location 268â†’uv run mcp-server-pocket-pick --database ./database.db 269â†’``` 270â†’ 271â†’## Other Useful MCP Servers 272â†’ 273â†’### Fetch 274â†’ 275â†’```bash 276â†’claude mcp file.content: # Pocket Pick (MCP Server) > > See how we used AI Coding, Claude Code, and MCP to build this tool on the [@IndyDevDan youtube channel](https://youtu.be/d-SyGA0Avtw). As engineers we end up reusing ideas, patterns and code snippets all the time but keeping track of these snippets can be hard and remembering where you stored them can be even harder. What if the exact snippet or idea you were looking for was one prompt away? With Anthropic's new MCP (Model Context Protocol) and a minimal portable database layer - we can solve this problem. Pocket Pick is your personal engineering knowledge base that lets you quickly store ideas, patterns and code snippets and gives you a DEAD SIMPLE text or tag based searching to quickly find them in the future. ## Features - **Personal Knowledge Base**: Store code snippets, information, and ideas - **Tag-Based Organization**: Add tags to categorize and filter your knowledge - **Flexible Search**: Find content using substring, full-text, glob, regex, or exact matching - **MCP Integration**: Seamlessly works with Claude and other MCP-compatible AI assistants - **SQLite Backend**: Fast, reliable, and portable database storage - **Command-Line Interface**: Easy to use from the terminal ## Installation Install [uv](https://docs.astral.sh/uv/getting-started/installation/) ```bash # Clone the repository git clone https://github.com/indydevdan/pocket-pick.git cd pocket-pick # Install dependencies uv sync ``` Usage from JSON format Default Database for Claude Code ```json { "command": "uv", "args": ["--directory", ".", "run", "mcp-server-pocket-pick"] } ``` Custom Database for Claude Code ```json { "command": "uv", "args": ["--directory", ".", "run", "mcp-server-pocket-pick", "--database", "./database.db"] } ``` ## Usage with Claude Code ### Using .mcp.json You can configure Pocket Pick in your project's `.mcp.json` file for easy integration with Claude Code: ```json { "servers": { "pocket-pick": { "command": "uv", "args": ["--directory", "/path/to/pocket-pick", "run", "mcp-server-pocket-pick"] } } } ``` With custom database location: ```json { "servers": { "pocket-pick": { "command": "uv", "args": ["--directory", "/path/to/pocket-pick", "run", "mcp-server-pocket-pick", "--database", "./custom-database.db"] } } } ``` Place this file in your project directory, and Claude Code will automatically detect and use the configured MCP servers when started in that directory. ```bash # Add the pocket-pick server to Claude Code (if you're in the directory) claude mcp add pocket-pick -- \ uv --directory . \ run mcp-server-pocket-pick # Add the pocket-pick server to Claude Code claude mcp add pocket-pick -- \ uv --directory /path/to/pocket-pick-codebase \ run mcp-server-pocket-pick # With custom database location claude mcp add pocket-pick -- \ uv --directory /path/to/pocket-pick-codebase \ run mcp-server-pocket-pick --database ./database.db # List existing MCP servers - Validate that the server is running claude mcp list # Start claude code claude ``` ## Pocket Pick MCP Tools The following MCP tools are available in Pocket Pick: | Tool | Description | | ---------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------- | | `pocket_add` | Add a new item with a specified ID to your knowledge base | | `pocket_add_file` | Add a file's content with a specified ID to your knowledge base | | `pocket_find` | Find items by text and/or tags | | `pocket_list` | List all items, optionally filtered by tags | | `pocket_list_tags` | List all tags with their counts | | `pocket_remove` | Remove an item by ID | | `pocket_get` | Get a specific item by ID | | `pocket_backup` | Backup the database | | `pocket_to_file_by_id` | Write an item's content to a file by its ID (requires absolute path) | ## Using with Claude After setting up Pocket Pick as an MCP server for Claude Code, you can use it your conversations: ### Adding Items Add items directly ```bash Add "claude mcp list" as a pocket pick item with ID "claude-mcp-list". tags: mcp, claude, code ``` Add items from clipboard ```bash pbpaste and create a pocket pick item with ID "python-fib" and the following tags: python, algorithm, fibonacci ``` Add items from a file ```bash Add the contents of ~/Documents/code-snippets/fibonacci.py to pocket pick with ID "fib-algorithm" and tags: python, algorithm, fibonacci ``` ### Listing Items List all items or tags: ``` list all my pocket picks ``` ### Finding Items Search for items in your knowledge base with tags ``` List pocket pick items with python and mcp tags ``` Search for text with specific content ``` pocket pick find "python" ``` ### Get or Remove Items Get or remove specific items: ``` get the pocket pick item with ID 1234-5678-90ab-cdef remove the pocket pick item with ID 1234-5678-90ab-cdef ``` ### Export to File Export a pocket pick item's content to a file by its ID. This allows you to save code snippets directly to files, create executable scripts from stored knowledge, or share content with others: ``` export the pocket pick item with ID 1234-5678-90ab-cdef to /Users/username/Documents/exported-snippet.py ``` The tool requires an absolute file path and will automatically create any necessary parent directories if they don't exist. ### Backup ``` backup the pocket pick database to ~/Documents/pocket-pick-backup.db ``` ## ID Management When adding items to Pocket Pick, you must now provide a unique ID: - IDs must be unique across your database - Choose descriptive IDs that help you identify the content - If you attempt to add an item with an ID that already exists, you'll receive an error ### ID Scheme Recommendations - **Descriptive IDs**: Use meaningful names like `python-sort-algorithm` or `css-flexbox-cheatsheet` - **Namespaced IDs**: Use prefixes like `py-`, `js-`, `css-` to categorize items - **UUID-style IDs**: Continue using UUIDs if you prefer automatically generated unique identifiers ## Search Modes Pocket Pick supports various search modes: - **substr**: (Default) Simple substring matching - **fts**: Full-text search with powerful capabilities: - Regular word search: Matches all words in any order (e.g., "python programming" finds entries with both words) - Exact phrase search: Use quotes for exact phrase matching (e.g., `"python programming"` only finds entries with that exact phrase) - **glob**: SQLite glob pattern matching (e.g., "test*" matches entries starting with "test") - **regex**: Regular expression matching - **exact**: Exact string matching Example find commands: ``` Find items containing "pyt" using substring matching Find items containing "def fibonacci" using full text search Find items containing "test*" using glob pattern matching Find items containing "^start.*test.*$" using regular expression matching Find items containing "match exactly test" using exact string matching ``` ## Database Structure Pocket Pick uses a simple SQLite database with the following schema: ```sql CREATE TABLE POCKET_PICK ( id TEXT PRIMARY KEY, -- UUID identifier created TIMESTAMP NOT NULL, -- Creation timestamp text TEXT NOT NULL, -- Item content tags TEXT NOT NULL -- JSON array of tags ) ``` The database file is located at `~/.pocket_pick.db` by default. ## Development ### Running Tests ```bash # Run all tests uv run pytest # Run with verbose output uv run pytest -v ``` ### Running the Server Directly ```bash # Start the MCP server uv run mcp-server-pocket-pick # With verbose logging uv run mcp-server-pocket-pick -v # With custom database location uv run mcp-server-pocket-pick --database ./database.db ``` ## Other Useful MCP Servers ### Fetch ```bash claude mcp add http-fetch -- uvx mcp-server-fetch ``` --- Built with â¤ï¸ by [IndyDevDan](https://www.youtube.com/@indydevdan) with [Claude Code](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/agents-and-tools/claude-code/overview), and [Principled AI Coding](https://agenticengineer.com/principled-ai-coding)
